text: the government is proposing to shake up the way rape trials are conducted in a bid to boost the number of convictions the solicitor general mike obrien said that while the number of complaints of rape had risen sharply convictions had only increased slightly speaking on the bbc radio today programme he said an awful lot of people who are committing rapes are getting away with it the proposed changes are contained in a consultation document aimed at increasing the conviction rate last year rapes were reported but only one in resulted in a conviction the home office minister fiona mctaggart said there is clear evidence that the mismatch between convictions and reports suggests there are people who have raped who dont get convicted one of the proposed changes is to make video interviews with rape victims automatically admissible in all cases currently they are only allowed when the victim is under these recordings which are often made within hours of the alleged offence might give juries a more detailed and accurate account of victims experiences the consultation document said i am trying to give juries the best possible evidence available if that evidence is the interview given to the police shortly after reporting the rape then the jury should be able to see that said mr obrien another proposal is to allow experts to give evidence about an alleged rape victims general behaviour after the attack this would bring the uk more in line with the way rape trials are conducted in the us canada and australia the director of public prosecutions ken macdonald said last year he was in favour of introducing expert witnesses to the courtroom to challenge the myths about victims behaviour for example jurors often find it difficult to understand why battered wives return to their abusers and fail to grasp why a victim might not report a rape for many weeks or months such apparently puzzling behaviour is often used by the defence as a basis for questioning in order to make victims appear unreliable or untruthful the government would also like to redefine the law on when a person consents to sex particularly if drugs or alcohol have been consumed what we need to do is make sure that where alcohol has been consumed and it affected the capacity of the victim then that matter should be put before the jury said mr obrien he pointed to a number of cases where judges had decided that a rape case should not be put before a jury because the alleged victim had been intoxicated and her evidence was hazy that is she could not say with absolute certainty that she did not consent

of the process its a lot of public money working in very poor communities how do we make it better you cant spend all that public money without evaluating it and bending it as you go we started something very radical and very new and the whole point is to learn about it we have a whole new system for nought to five year olds and we have to make sure we learn the lessons of this very large text: prosecutors in date rape cases will be freed to call expert witnesses on the trauma of sex crimes to shatter juries misconceptions about the crime under plans to boost convictions to be unveiled this week victims who delay reporting the alleged attack or appear unusually composed in the witness box should no longer be treated with suspicion the consultation paper from the solicitor general mike obrien will argue the witnesses could describe how a traumatised victim might require time to raise the courage to go to police why she might have stayed with an abusive partner factors that might lead a jury to doubt her story or the ways in which she might respond to giving evidence the law on consent will also be clarified to protect women who are too drunk to be capable of consenting to sex putting the onus back on the defence to prove that a woman who was incapable through alcohol was actually a willing partner video testimony from womens interviews with police in the immediate aftermath of a rape when they are likely to have been most distressed could also be permitted in courts the changes will affect all rape cases but will be most relevant to socalled date rapes where the attacker was known to the victim and where juries have proved more reluctant to convict than rapes committed by strangers rape is an appalling crime that devastates the lives of victims and their families the conviction rate is too low and we need to do something about it said a source close to the solicitor general the consultation paper forms part of a concerted effort by ministers this week to show they take violence against women seriously after damaging leaks of plans by the independent sentencing advisory council to reduce rape sentences junior home office minister fiona mactaggart will announce plans to protect prostitutes from violent clients while her colleague baroness scotland will unveil plans for advisers to help victims of domestic and sexual violence through court only one in rape allegations ends in a guilty verdict acquaintance rapes are the most common but most difficult to prosecute while even in stranger rape cases perceptions of the victim have proved crucial to the trial and sentencing the expert witnesses would not testify specifically about the victims mental state but would present general evidence on the psychology of sexattack victims they could also tackle common assumptions such as that a scantily clad woman must have been asking for it or to blame the paper will also call for either a change in the law or new guidance for judges on cases where the victim is drunk or high on drugs

text: setting aside the rank commercialisation of yet another religious festival tomorrow is a day for reflecting on the value of motherhood but if that sounds as saccharine as the preprinted wording of a mothers day card how does a year sound that is how much it would cost to contract out all the household jobs that the average mum does without any pecuniary reward the average fathers contribution on the other hand is measured at just the difference between sexes boils down to who does what in the home mothers are reckoned to spend hours a week on household jobs including hours of childcare while fathers spend hours including hours with the children women also do significantly more cooking housekeeping family shopping and taxiing the kids around it would cost the average family a week to pay someone else to do a mothers job with childcare being the biggest weekly outlay at followed by housekeeping at in london the total cost is more than a week mothers with fulltime jobs outside the home spend more time on domestic and family chores than they do in their paid place of work more than hours a week on average the total for fulltime mothers at home is hours and to contract out their unpaid duties would cost a year each these figures which appear in the insurer legal amp generals latest value of a mum survey highlight the expense of raising children and the often unseen value of parenthood they also prove that traditional gender roles still exist in the home despite the record level of economic activity among mothers but could the division of parental duties also explain the pay gap between men and women the average hourly pay of working mums with dependent children is a third less than that of working fathers according to a department for work and pensions dwp report published in january before they have children women earn just less than men working women experience particularly low wage growth in the two or three years after each birth whereas this is the period when their male colleagues experience particularly high wage growth says mike brewer coauthor of the dwp report the pay difference doesnt start to shrink until years after each birth but it never disappears entirely brewers report offers no reasons why hourly pay is so different from our data we cannot say there is discrimination against mothers on the other hand some mothers are able to escape the pay penalty more than others particularly women in the public sector he says but it could be that women with children have less power in the labour market and are forced to accept lower wages for the kind of work that is more family friendly women returning to work after starting a family also face greater discrimination than disabled people according to research by professor richard berthoud of the institute for economic research at the university of essex mothers of children under the age of whether with or without a partner are less likely to have a job than a man with a partner he says discrimination against motherhood continues despite years of equal opportunities legislation for example a womans right to return to her old job after maternity leave or a job of the equivalent value is now protected by law however a lot of women find that on returning to work they have been effectively demoted says rob holdsworth at the equal opportunities commission eoc during their maternity leave they have been passed over for promotion and pay rises in a survey last november the recruitment and employment confederation found of recruitment agencies had been asked by employers not to hire women who were pregnant or of childbearing age despite this being illegal almost half of pregnant women suffer unfair treatment at work according to the eoc britain is the only eu state where workers can opt out of the working time directive the tuc believes that scrapping the optout and making all jobs workable parttime could bring greater equality for mothers rebecca gill at the tuc says enabling men to leave work and spend time with their children will enable women to work more and thereby reduce the employment penalty that motherhood brings but if men are to take a more active part in home life they also need to change their attitudes towards work men tend not to factor parenthood into their careers and still see themselves as breadwinners tomorrows celebration of motherhood might be a chance for dads to reflect on their roles too the fulltime mother i absolutely made the right decision bridget gilchrist who lives in south london with her husband justin and three children beth daniel and jessie worked for a middle east information group in parliament for more than a dozen years she left the world of westminster to be a fulltime mother in i took six months maternity leave for each of my children but with my first beth i went back to working am to pm four days a week later on i decreased my working week to three days then to two days on a job share ive used a whole range of childcare options from childminders to shared nannies to au pairs childcare generally accounted for half of what i earned ive always done the lions share of household jobs even when i was working four days a week but justin has done the lions share of keeping the household finances going ive had help from au pairs in the past but now i do of the household chores my decision to be a fulltime mother was partly financial as we could afford for me to stop but mainly i felt that all my children needed me to be with them much more than i had been and i can see now that it is absolutely the right decision before i was constantly rushing from one thing to the next and never taking time to think what i needed to do our son has special needs and we had him at home for four years doing a home teaching programme it required an enormous amount of research and preparation the acquisition of new skills on our part and consistency although he now goes to school fulltime there is a large element of that still i do miss work and the status it brings my colleagues were surprised when i decided to leave because it came quite late on in my career but because im a little bit older i have less to prove and im clearer about what is important when i was younger i thought that i had to be campaigning and that this was the most important thing in the world i handed my first child over to a childminder when she was five months without a blink but i wouldnt be able to do that now my priorities changed and while i loved my work and the world of politics ive made the right decision and been very fortunate to be able to do so

text: the coverage of sex discrimination cases has such a standard template that it is hard to believe that articles like these are written by human beings rather than being produced by a keyboard macro there are three ingredients to such a story a wellgroomed woman a salacious anecdote and a huge sum of money you have a choice of two flavours of article of course if one is writing for a leftwing newspaper or for the womens section the story is isnt it terrible that these highly paid bankers did these terrible things to this reasonably attractive woman if one is writing for a rightwing newspaper or for the business section the story is isnt this a huge amount of money that this reasonably attractive woman is getting for this fairly minor slight not optional of course is a big colour picture of the plaintiff usually showing a fair amount of leg to get over the fact that this is a sex discrimination story but usually showing little or no cleavage to emphasis that is is a sex discrimination story the facts of these cases as presented are always here is a woman she had her bum pinched or her breasts commented on or whatever and now she is suing her employers for several million pounds which is why win or lose the plaintiffs in these cases always end up being the object of uncomprehending jealousy most people have a fairly major problem in understanding why someone should get more compensation for being jokingly invited to a lapdancing club or asked to give someone a shoulder massage than one typically gets for having a leg chopped off and inevitably the end result is articles like this one saying that it looks really bad for the sisterhood if women are such crybabies and who will want to employ them if a simple comment can land the firm with a sevenfigure settlement the facts in the newspaper are not the facts let me explain every year in the big banks there is something called a bonus round during this period some people are given large sums of money some people are given significantly smaller sums of money and some people are given nothing at all just to clarify here when i say large sums of money i mean between a quarter of a million and a million pounds and yes thank you i am aware how that compares to a nurses salary its called capitalism and it doesnt look like its going anywhere any time soon so can we get on with this blog post please the people in the significantly smaller and nothing at all bonus groups are usually unhappy about the fact if someone thinks that they have been unfairly screwed on their bonus because they are a woman what are they going to do except sue having made the decision to sue the case usually falls into the hands of a specialist lawyer the lawyer will typically want to settle the case out of court for a large sum of money and a quick turnover the way that you persuade people to settle out of court is to convince them that a whole load of bad and embarrassing publicity will come out for them if they dont settle soon hence the client is asked to dredge through her memory for bad behaviour that will look really awful in the cold light of day or in the newspapers boys being boys it is unlikely that there will be a shortage of material because sex discrimination stories are written according to the template the bad publicity does indeed arrive if the case isnt settled promptly and so the case gets settled or maybe it goes to trial i have no specific information about the merits of any of these cases but the fact is that if the case is about sixfigure bonuses and the plaintiff reckons shes been done out of of them then the settlement is going to be a sevenfigure sum the actual case and certainly the settlement has nothing to do with the pinching poking and stripping and everything to do with the allegation of unfairness over bonuses but the world is allowed to believe that in the modern financial sector comparing someone to pamela anderson is a crime on a par with multiple murder to be met with financial settlements on the scale of a footballers divorce i can quite understand why these cases are in general covered so badly no editor on earth is going to print a story about the rights and wrongs of who got given the credit for the xyz deal and who got screwed when there is the alternative of writing a mildly salacious one about dirty old men and strip clubs i have sat in enough wine bars with colleagues male and female to know that there is nothing on earth duller than a bitter story about the unfairness of a particular banks bonus regime but perhaps from time to time the readers could at least have it suggested to them that there is a little bit more to it than that

text: social progress often comes at a price and the emancipation of women is no exception it is the mark of a confident successful liberal society that it can acknowledge and face up to the negative consequences of social advance and put in place appropriate policies to mitigate them whether it is the loosening of social solidarity as a result of growing diversity or the question of how to replace the female altruism that has been central to caring for the young and the old as women spend more time at work politics can come up with solutions but first the problem has to be acknowledged in the case of the negative consequences of female emancipation it is rare to find a hardheaded evaluation of the losses to society when women especially educated ones choose work over family the newspapers are so full of stories about pay gaps and glass ceilings that sometimes they miss the bigger and still remarkably recent story that for the first time in history women in developed societies have no career or occupation barred to them politicians journalists and business people often stress the negative effects of losing half the countrys best brains to the kitchen sink and of course they are right to do so the feminisation of the labour market especially at the higher professional end has brought enormous benefits but it is striking how seldom anyone mentions let alone tries to quantify the offsetting losses when women choose work over family one of the reasons the female labour market story has appeared so unambiguously positive over recent decades is the buried assumption that women were not really doing anything of value when they were working mainly in the home the american economist shirley burggraf has noted the strange alliance on this issue between feminists and market economists the former see domestic labour as performed under patriarchal duress the latter do not consider labour in the home at all because it is not paid and so does not text: jail sentences for rapists are to be slashed under controversial new guidelines for judges revealed just days before an official campaign against rape is launched by the government in a move which critics warned would deter traumatised women from reporting sex crimes the sentencing guidelines council sgc is to recommend that future sentences for rape and other sexual offences be cut by per cent for most offenders the observer can reveal that the council an independent body advising the judiciary on how to interpret the law will argue that men should serve shorter sentences because the prison regime is now more demanding in a separate move it is also expected to recommend shortly that men convicted of domestic violence could escape jail terms if they convince the courts they are capable of changing instead they would be sent on courses in the community challenging their attitudes to women these moves would relieve pressure on britains overcrowded prisons but mps and womens groups said they sent the wrong message about the crimes many women fear most while victims could be dissuaded from the ordeal of testifying if they feared the result would only be a short sentence the proposals appear sharply at odds with government attempts to tackle violence against women coming amid a home office advertising campaign warning men to seek womens consent to sex and new plans from the attorney general to boost rape convictions there has been a big struggle to get rape and domestic violence recognised as serious terrible crimes and i do have concerns said julie morgan the labour mp and chair of the allparty group on sex equality it is a terrible struggle for women to bring these cases to court and i dont think we ought to give the message that we think these crimes should be dealt with in a lighter way domestic violence kills one woman every two to three days in the uk while the british crime survey recently estimated one in women has been raped the proposals to cut rape and sexual offence sentences in line with proposals for other violent crimes like robbery will be published for consultation with guidelines finalised later this year the average sentence for rape is now seven years and four months joanne savage secretary to the sgc said it took into account the argument that custodial sentences had become more demanding recently with those sent to prison spending at least half their sentence behind bars once released they are placed under supervision often with strict restrictions until the end of their licence period this is a significant change and people released into the community under supervision from probation officers are at greater risk of being recalled savage said the move will not affect rapists already in prison in some cases rape must still mean life sentences controversially the council will also set out grounds where mitigating circumstances will be taken into account they are expected to include cases involving sexual familiarity between rapist and victim before the attackthat could mean a woman and a man becoming intimate with the woman later refusing full sex only to be overpowered such date rapes where victims know their attacker are the most common form of rape critics accused the government of allowing a uturn on violent crime given that the earlier policy of longer sentences contributed to the fall in crime since the midnineties the new strategy will jeopardise public safety and the key target to reduce crime by per cent by said blair gibbs crime research officer at the right of centre thinktank reform rape charities said the changes risked damaging womens confidence in the legal system the decision on whether to go to court will be harder if women think the rapist will not receive an adequate sentence said a spokeswoman for south essex rape and incest crisis centre the domestic violence proposals would affect men committing sufficiently violent attacks to be jailed but able to text: growing numbers of men are rejecting the culture of working long hours in favour of spending more time at home according to a study which reveals a social revolution is taking place as fathers become increasingly involved in bringing up their children men are a substantial and fastrising proportion of those seeking their employers permission to work flexitime with shorter hours or fewer days but they face more obstacles to securing a better worklife balance than women in the last two years million men around per cent of the male workforce have asked their employer if they can work flexibly that is far less than the million women per cent who have sought the same change in their hours but a big increase on previous years the figures are from an examination of britains changing work habits produced for the tuc by three academics called out of time why britain needs a new approach to workingtime flexibility which is published this week more men are seeking the right to switch to working flexitime a nineday fortnight or fourday week so they can be around to help their children and partners and even more would do so if the rules on flexible working were changed so that all workers not just parents could do that said jo morris the tucs worklife balance policy officer jenny watson the chair of the equal opportunities commission said the tucs research confirmed that britain was in the middle of a social revolution in how much time fathers want to spend with their families more fathers are more concerned to be more involved with their families than ever before their desire to do so is moving faster than politicians attitude to this this is a very private revolution which often happens within a family that has to make a decision about childcare and it has gone relatively unnoticed by those making public policy said watson despite action by the government to help new parents paternity leave needed to be extended from its current twoweek minimum and rates of pay for men taking it should be increased to make it easier for them to spend time with a baby added watson while some employers are good on flexible working in other workplaces there can be an assumption that flexible working is for mothers and fathers can find it not just hard to get but even hard to ask for it because the prevailing culture is that if you request it you arent serious about your job said watson since april parents of children under six have been able to ask their employer to vary their hours of work but employers are only legally obliged to give reasonable consideration to such requests the tucs research shows that four in men are not granted all of the changed hours they have requested compared to three in women while one in seven men but one in women have their application rejected completely employers greater unwillingness to let male workers change their hours is unhealthy because it reinforces the pattern of women with children often being locked into lowhours and lowpaid jobs and deepens womens financial dependence on men such as in their pension prospects in old age said morris the tuc eoc and chartered institute of personnel and development want all workers to be able to work flexibly regardless of whether they have children as is already the case in some european countries although allowing flexible working leads to happier more productive employees and greater staff retention some employers see it as difficult to implement and unfair to other workers there is a slow but definite trend towards a woman being the breadwinner in a growing number of households the number of men choosing not to work at all so that they can look after their home or their children has risen from around in to by the end of according she works monday to thursday as a teacher which is a very inflexible occupation so i asked the council if instead of working from am to pm i could work from am to pm from monday to thursday during term time and my normal hours during the weeks of school holidays it operates a worklife balance policy and practises what it preaches previously i was out of the house by am leaving kirstin to get tia and stan who is two fed dressed and to the childminder by am before going to work herself which was a tall order now kirstin is happier im glad that i have been able to help her and tia appreciates being walked to school by her dad

text: once upon a time when a man had a daughter one of his main concerns was how to foot the wedding bill now he is more anxious to cushion her against inequality so if research completed this week is correct he casts his vote according to what he sees as his daughters best interests and they surprisingly perhaps to some lie on the left a range of influences attract people to the left but according to professor andrew oswald of the university of warwick and dr nattavudh powdthavee of the london institute of education significant among those influences is the presence of daughters in their study submitted to an american academic journal they say that if a man fathers a girl the likelihood of him voting for a leftwing party defined generously as labour or liberal democrat increases by for each daughter oswald and powdthavee employ mathematical formulae and tentative conjecture to argue that leftwing individuals come from extended families into which over recent past generations many females have been born they have found that strings of daughters through the generations lead to leftwing families today think tony booth and his many daughters or the late john smith and his three while strings of sons move parents rightwards so why do sons and daughters have a different political impact on parents moving into tricky darwinian waters oswald says that the raison detre of the majority of parents is to see their children prosper and achieve happiness the more contented the children the better the chances of them breeding thus securing the genetic line since most females still face inequality parents subconsciously see this as an impediment to contentment as a result their support shifts to a party that pledges to help the disadvantaged the argument continues women in the main face pay discrimination and are largely responsible for childcare so they rely more on services provided by the public sector services in which labour has traditionally invested compared with males females are more in favour of higher taxes to fund provision such as the nhs higher taxation also affects them less since they tend to be in a lowerincome bracket as men acquire female children oswald and powdthavee write those men gradually shift their political stance and become more sympathetic to the female desire for a larger amount for the public good they become more left wing similarly a mother with sons becomes sympathetic to the male case for lower taxes and a smaller supply of public goods the thesis appears to be blown out of the water by a quick trot around the stately homes of england aristocratic families have had squadrons of daughters and never wavered from being true blue nevertheless the authors insist that as a broader trend their argument has statistical robustness oswald and powdthavee drew their data from the british household panel survey for the years to monitoring adults in households among parents with three sons and no daughters voted left in households with three daughters and no sons voted for the left among switchers the trend is even more marked in the year period switched from left to right switched from right to left the voters who swung from right to left had on average more daughters the trend left prevails regardless of income education or employment since as yet we are not allowed to order up the gender of our offspring the academics argue it is the daughters who supply the x factor for the left when it comes to the ballot box in other words children shape parents oswald and powdthavee also argue that women are inherently collectivist while men are more individualistic biological determinism has for centuries imprisoned the aspirations of men and women certainly that inherent female collectivism was not evident from the postwar era until the thatcherite s then women voted in greater numbers for the tories as the party of the family that emphasised the responsibility of the individual to provide for his and it was his own what is clear however is that men and women view politics through a very different lens because of who does what on a daily basis women make up almost half the labour market but they also carry out the overwhelming majority of housework childcare and caring for elderly dependants work by academics including rosie campbell of birkbeck college london and pippa norris of harvard university show how this ethic of care has an impact on political attitudes internationally young women in particular have been moving to the left it might be assumed that as they become better educated and their income rises they will be less concerned with the public good and adopt what oswald and powdthavee term individualistic male attitudes however regardless of womens individual economic status in focus groups and voting habits many still have a concern for the particular needs and experiences of others perhaps because of this connection with the world of unpaid care labour tapped into that in but women arent easily bought off and their concerns also embrace civil liberties the economy and iraq in more than of women voted the next general election may see the lowest turn out since when only of voters truned out the local elections next week may not fare much better large swathes of women particularly the unders who helped to give labour its original victory are on electoral strike against what many see as a conservative greedy divisive government that takes on a more feminine face only during elections the think tank demos has talked of this as widespread political disconnection others talk of apathy as if it is a disease of the young another reading is far more radical many women young and old are deeply interested in politics they turn out in higher numbers when a woman stands for parliament not because they are sexist but because she may represent a difference in style priorities and content norris applies the theory of critical mass from nuclear physics to politics and change in society nuclear reaction can be contained only to a certain point when enough uranium is assembled an unstoppable chain reaction occurs women have yet to reach that critical mass in politics once they do the policy agenda political discourse and the look of institutions will alter radically for both left and right the tragedy is that labours betrayal may forfeit the opportunity to achieve that critical mass if women do not get into the habit of voting young they tend never to acquire the habit katherine rake director of the fawcett society which campaigns to close the inequality gap says its research shows an increasing proportion of young women are radical but alienated from westminster what we have via the internet and blogging is a huge amount of very angry young women whats missing is a focus for that energy if oswald and powdthavee are right we face a paradox while daughters act as a catalyst on their parents political belief they themselves in increasing numbers are doing nothing to exercise their democratic muscle in elections because no party adequately reflects their views as a result power is retained not just by the right of centre but also by the traditional white male establishment unless that is that mysterious alchemy seen at work in france occurs here and daughters take to the streets miracles can happen

text: it used to be my guilty secret i only ever whispered the n word to my very closest friends if pressed i might talk about my childminder a lie but far easier to live with and rather less likely to attract tuttutting after all how could a selfrespecting leftleaning professional woman do such a thing but now at last i can confess i employ a nanny to look after my children nannies once the butt of jokes and the sole preserve of the wellheeled are now an everyday option and increasingly the preferred choice for ordinary working parents and nanny employers like me once a silent slightly embarrassed minority are standing up to be counted a survey this week compiled from nanny employment agencies by a nannysharing website called sharingcouk appears to show that the number of nannies in britain has now risen to more than for the first time what could account for such a rise the first reason must be money these days employing a nanny is about reducing costs not increasing class status according to the daycare trust nursery fees have soared over the past five years outstripping inflation by more than in london a fulltime nursery place costs around per week some nurseries charge up to per year if you have two preschool children as i once did its often cheaper to employ one person in your home than pay for two places in the local nursery according to graham newton who runs a payroll company called nannypaye recent government financial incentives such as childcare vouchers make nannies an even more attractive option and despite reports of the modern nanny demanding city banker incomes newtons experience is that salaries have settled the influx of labour from the new european countries has made a difference he says they may not be ukqualified but they fulfil the upmarket au pair role it has capped the wages nannies are demanding making them slightly more reasonable its cheaper still if you share that nanny with friends or a neighbour as is increasingly happening an estimated of nannies are now looking after children from more than one family the internet has made it far easier to chum up enter your postcode on a site such as thenannysharerscouk and you can be linked with a compatible family close by sharing also overcomes the major drawback to having your very own nanny before my kids started school and i had a secret sole nanny i felt obliged to take them along to every saturday morning activity on offer so that they spent time with likeminded minimates with nanny sharing your kids have builtin friends then there is the flexibility you get from a nanny checking your kids in to a nursery at am and picking them up at pm is fine if your job is as regular as clockwork and you can guarantee the phone wont ring just as you are walking away from your desk but that often isnt the case in real life liz bayram chief executive of the national childminding association which includes nannies says flexibility is at the heart of a nannys appeal having a nanny may be the only way you can have siblings looked after together and you cant phone up a nursery to say youre running a bit late and could they pick up your child from its football club like the vast majority of working parents flexible childcare makes my working life possible dropping the kids off at nursery en route to the first interview is a major manoeuvre i know ive tried it for more than a year i didnt only have to worry about not having posset on my suit but also having three kids all brushed and washed by am with a nanny your kids can work to their timetable not yours the delight of being able to hand them over first thing still cornflakeencrusted and in their pyjamas is immeasurable for all concerned and if you have a child with any special need from disability to longterm illness care outside the home often isnt an option only a nanny will do what you would if you were around nannies too do far more than childcare if you are running out of washing powder you cant ask the nursery assistant to pick up a packet on the way back from the park or if you are rushing out the door in the morning to catch the and your fouryear old has just spilt its frosties all over the floor you hope they wont still be there when you get back at seven that night a nanny may not clean but she nearly always wipes these are all possetive reasons to have nannies but there are also negative ones the rise and rise of the british nanny has been attributed to the dripdrip effect of documentaries showing abusive nursery assistants plopping toddlers on dirty potties but i for one think that safety is a poor reason to opt for a nanny day nurseries are stringently regulated by ofsted and are legally required to carry out background checks on all staff says purnima tanuku chief executive of the national day nurseries association nannies are not regulated in the same way so its important that parents carefully check references qualifications and experience i have used a local authority nursery as well as a nanny and discovered that checks for anyone employed outside the home are far greater than for anyone employed inside my current nanny is policechecked and registered but in the past ive been fooled i once employed a woman with excellent written references of course i phoned her former employer just to double check she told me the children had grown so fond of her that they called her auntie it was several months later that i discovered why the former employer was in fact the nannys sister she really was their auntie after all another perhaps notsopossetive reason for choosing a nanny is our belief in the benefits of oneonone over oneonmany childcare having a nanny gives us the illusion if not the reality of control who really knows what happens when you wave goodbye each morning i have learned that we can only exercise certain limits if we employ professional women to look after our children then we have to trust them laying down the law about what they are given for tea in your absence may be as far as you can go but many parents like to think that a nanny is more likely to play their offspring baby mozart and practice n for nanny than a childminder would with a crowd of kids to control one friend once phoned me in rage she had caught her nanny committing the crime of reading a newspaper while she was supposed to be looking after the threeyear old she didnt employ her to do that i laughed but isnt that exactly what a parent would do i want a nanny but one with a soft and slovenly heart my three children have now started school but i still employ a nanny neither my life nor my childrens are very regimented so it suits us all best in fact i wouldnt have been able to write this article without her

text: as few as of men convicted of domestic violence are sent to prison while a clear majority escape with a fine according to new home office figures published this week the official breakdown of sentences passed by specialist domestic violence courts show that there are more than one million victims of domestic violence as much as five times higher than previously recognised the disclosure text: as glass ceilings go it tends to be the salary and promotion inequalities that grab all the attention however in the arena of claiming expenses there is also evidence that some organisations are discriminating against women the average man employee in the uk spends nearly more a night on a hotel room during a business trip than the average female employee compared with according to research by globalexpense a specialist outsource firm that handles staff expenses claims for employers such as sainsburys wh smith roche and renault and the difference between the sexes does not end with the cost of a bed for the night while in a hotel men spend more on inroom entertainment including satellite tv room service and minibars says david vine the director of globalexpense the differences in attitude to expenses among men and women is also highlighted by a survey of expenseaccount travellers published last month barclaycards business travel survey shows that while of men claim expenses without a receipt only of their female colleagues are given the same privilege and while women are more likely than men to use the train for business trips they are significantly less likely compared with to travel first class when they do so the survey also shows that women who account for of managers in the uk travel only half as many miles as men do for work and are less likely to stay away from home overnight tim carlier the head of card issuing at barclaycard business believes the differences may come down to experience women are less experienced in business travel than men and this is perhaps why their approach to expenses is more conservative he says if their company policy is to claim firstclass rail travel for example though i certainly think they should take advantage of it although women can be modest when it comes to spending on their own comfort they tend to splash out more on client entertainment or team jollies according to globalexpense vine says the average woman employees expenses claim on client entertainment is compared with a more parsimonious for men while a woman managers expenses bill for entertaining her team or members of her department is almost double that claimed by her male counterparts despite womens apparent reluctance to cane their personal expenses it seems that their claims sheet come under greater scrutiny than those put in by men according to the credit card firm visas eu business travel survey a third of women business travellers have their expenses routinely questioned including their use of taxis entertainment budgets hotel room service personal telephone calls and newspaper or magazine bills this compares with of men business travellers who say their expenses are similarly scrutinised although visas survey was carried out in many believe the situation has not changed the attitude in my firm is that i am lucky at to have a job that entails so much foreign travel and i shouldnt push my luck by overclaiming on expenses says one woman travel agent my male colleagues though are expected and tacitly encouraged to claim more or less what they like on bar bills or latenight taxis and they feel quite relaxed about doing so male tardiness may also explain the differences in the expense culture the barclaycard survey shows that of men compared with of women take up to a month to hand in their expenses claims and are therefore less likely perhaps to have them pored over by eagleeyed bosses meanwhile of women make expenses an immediate priority on their return from a business trip there are four explanations for the expenses inequity between men and women first as more experienced business travellers men are less scrupulous than women and are more likely to alter a to or pass off friday nights chinese meal for five mates as a legitimate business meeting second and as barclaycards survey shows women are far quicker at handing in expense sheets making it easier to scrutinise every phone call and taxi third womens position in many organisations remains tenuous and they are still expected or even encouraged to spend less on client entertaining or on travel than their male counterparts despite years of legislation outlawing discrimination on the grounds of gender many pieces of research have shown that as women move up the career ladder they tend to receive less pay and fewer perks such as new company cars or bigger offices than men so to discover that their expenses are also clipped is no great surprise to me says marilyn davidson a professor of work psychology at manchester business school to continually question a womans expenses on behalf of the firm is to denigrate her professional standing and to keep her in a subordinate position its not something many men would tolerate and finally while senior women tend to be far rarer and therefore more visible than senior men in many organis ations making even a routine expenses sheet more likey to be questioned women themselves must shoulder some blame for such scrutiny adds davidson women often sit back and say that they are more interested in doing their job well than claiming first class travel or demanding the latest company car but in the long run this refusal to fight for the same treatment as their male counterparts does them no good she says until they understand that their status in the eyes of colleagues and clients can often rest on perks such as better offices or more generous expense accounts they will continue to enjoy less status and influence at work according to the budget hotel chain travelodge which recently produced its own survey of travel expenses in association with office angels the most eyepopping expenses claims tend to be submitted thirdhand by pas and secretaries on behalf of superiors among the most outrageous claims uncovered by travelodge last year was a bill for the respray of a private helicopter and a fourfigure sum for a business meeting held in a wellknown lapdancing club while these two business expenses were happily honoured by the companies concerned another bill was not a expense claim for a replacement pair of shoes and trousers for the manager who stepped in wet cement outside his new office building was roundly rejected

text: my dad used to drop my siblings and me off at school each morning on the way to work wed listen to the radio and chat about our day and i was oblivious to the fact that this was the s and for a man to say to his office that he wouldnt be in before am because he was doing the school run was very unusual he got a lot of stick for it but thats the way it worked in my house fast forward years and things are changing slowly a mums struggle makes daily headlines having a baby will cost me hundreds of thousands over my lifetime according to one report parenthood is seen as a mums dilemma but new government research suggests that now dads are speaking up too the survey of mothers of month old babies and of the childrens fathers revealed that dads are now deeply involved in their kids upbringing the proportion of fathers working flexible hours to fit around childcare arrangements rose from to between and the number working from home doubled from to its all part say fathers campaigning groups of a real change in the home and workplace this is evidence that there is a social revolution going on with fathers not just talking about being more involved with their children but renegotiating their lives to allow for it says jack osullivan of information charity fathers direct its really good for children families and fathers themselves who get the benefit of being a dad the renegotiating of dads roles includes working shorter hours said they did moving their working day backward or forward to fit around their families changing hours to fit with their partners work and changing jobs altogether its just what my dad did bar the change of job but back in the s when the yuppy working culture meant am board meetings and hour days my dads logic that he was working to pm most days so a am start was fair did not go down well some believe little has changed we need to modernise the laws to keep up to track with the speed of this social change to let fathers play the part they want to play in their childrens lives says osullivan one of the governments proposals on this front is that parents should be able to share their parental leave allowance so that parents could decide how to share out the years leave when a new child is born this will be a popular option for some parents but could also cause some rows a quarter of mums said they would consider sharing some of their months of parental leave with their partner but a third of new fathers would like the option to spend longer with their small children announcing the research conducted by the policy study institute trade and industry secretary alan johnson said there had been a positive culture change in the home and workplace mothers are taking more time off when their child is born the majority of fathers are taking up their new entitlement to paternity leave and the number of new dads now working flexibly has tripled he claimed the findings in the page report were evidence that the governments policy is working after maternity leave was extended from to weeks and unpaid additional leave from to weeks last year half of mothers took weeks leave compared with in and a further took the full weeks compared with just three years previously but while the government is trumpeting the improved takeup of maternity and paternity leave and the evidence that dads are getting more involved women who have children are still counting the cost to their careers some months after the birth of their child one in four mothers were not working some had attempted a return to work only to give it up later but fewer mothers switched jobs when they returned something the reports authors suggested showed employers were taking their commitments to working mothers more seriously three quarters of women who were not working said that they wanted to spend more time with their children but said they couldnt afford childcare said their job didnt provide suitable hours and could not find the right childcare the most likely to return to work were those in higher level jobs with better flexible working opportunities or those with heavy mortgage commitments the governments report did not ask the same questions of the fathers why simply because so few are providing the principal care for their children dads might be more involved but shifting their working day is not the same as shifting their entire careers carena rogers policy officer at the national family and parenting institute says mothers are still much more pressured to give up their careers and it can be very difficult to get back into work my dad might have been a trailblazer but theres still a way to go

text: this is not about being antisex this is not a call for a return to a puritan past where intercourse was had and not heard it is not about being prudish or easily embarrassed or unliberated but it is about anger about feeling shortchanged and wanting to shake awake the majority of us who have been badgered into apathy by the sexual saturation of modern western culture it is about taking back control of sex its meaning and its representation from the market before its too late its about celebrating the human freedom that sex embodies how desire can take us to the heart of our greatest potential that in a moment we might be anybody or anything is this really our world where it is no longer strange to see pictures of breasts on the side of buses where it is considered hip for middleclass men and women to visit swanky lapdancing clubs while remaining oblivious to the continuum of exploitation that links those polished performers with the crackaddicted working girls on the street corner where celebrity magazines detail at length the copulation techniques of minor celebrities but their readers remain unable to choose on any given night whether theyd rather sleep alone a third of young women say that they have been coerced into sex similar data for young men does not exist but i wonder how often they too feel pinioned by expectation this is what sexual liberation coopted by commerce has delivered for women and men a few years ago germaine greer pointed out that while in the s she had fought for womens right to say yes to sex and not to be judged for their appetites nowadays she felt appalled that women no longer had the right to say no for fear of being branded inhibited and repressed the values of the market have turned sex into a competitive sport better faster in ever more inventive contortions the raunch culture identified by the american writer ariel levy puts forward poledancing lessons and nostrings liaisons as evidence of liberation because women are apparently now able to consume sex on an equal footing with men female sexuality is celebrated as increasingly voracious yet the images of women presented by advertisers are eager to please easy to satisfy and as challenging as a blowup doll but how does the white noise of public sex affect personal sexual development there is some evidence that teenagers are becoming more confident about reporting rapes and sexual assaults but if younger women know that they have the right not to be abused they still dont think they have the right to satisfying respectful sex as the brilliant movie kidulthood about the lives of adolescents growing up in west london documents starkly to desire and be desired can be many things funny awkward transforming sacred and profane to be honest about what turns you on demands a particularly intimate bravery but for all we are overinformed about how other people while away their bedroom hours about whats hot and whats not men and women are no closer to developing a common erotic language indeed it seems that that private language is being gradually eradicated from the public domain by the megaphone imperialism of cultural sexism it is a reasonable question to ask do men and women bring the same expectations to sexual intercourse most national surveys show that women want sex less often than men experience orgasm less often and find greater satisfaction in emotional intimacy than in genital sex but does this really mean that women are naturally cuddlecentric finding it impossible to separate sex from love some would suggest that the higher male sex drive has a darwinian rationale i lean towards a more cultural explanation that young girls are taught from an early age that sex is part of a romantic narrative involving love partnership and children while boys are told that it is a discrete act underpinning masculinity the teenagers i know still find themselves stuck with the slapperstud convention around promiscuity it seems to me that we need gender as much as sex education in our schools the process of expressing our wanting of another person is necessarily opaque seduction is by its nature a masque but this is very different from the wholesale sexual irresponsibility encouraged by cultural sexism on these pages last saturday madeleine bunting charted the way that the expectation of sexual availability leads both men and women to outsource the role of seducer to media culture we have been conned into choosing the faux rebellion of visiting a strip club over the far more taxing mutiny of taking full responsibility for how why and with whom we want to have sex there can be no prescription too many moralisers have tried and failed to codify desire but we need to stop fooling ourselves that we can translate the sleazy simulacrum of sexual freedom from the billboards into our personal lives to live the kind of sexual lives that are genuinely liberated responsible and pleasurable were going to need a new manifesto the story of childhood by libby brooks is published by bloomsbury on july libbybrookstheguardiancom

text: thousands of women in britain may have been shortchanged on statutory maternity pay over the past year because of faulty computer software used to calculate their entitlements for employees who qualify statutory maternity pay smp is payable at per cent of average weekly earnings for the first six weeks of maternity leave then or per cent of average earnings whichever is lower a week for the next weeks previously average earnings were worked out from the qualifying or set period defined as the th week before the week in which the baby is due any increase in the womans earnings between the end of the set period and the end of her maternity leave was thus ignored for the purposes of the calculation unless the pay rise was backdated to the set period in however the european court of justice ecj ruled that from april any pay rise awarded at any time from the beginning of the set period to the end of the maternity leave period would have to be included in the calculation for smp if more than one pay rise was awarded they would all have to be included in the calculation but whether or not an employer is aware of this obligation seems to depend on where it gets its information her majestys revenue and customs hmrc supplies hundreds of thousands of employers with a cdrom that helpfully includes an smp calculator but it doesnt factor in the pay rise issue nor does hmrcs online calculator and its e help book pay and time off work for parents doesnt mention it either the ruling is mentioned in e supplement pay and time off work for parents special cases which is included on the cdrom but not every employer will have read it especially as e describes special cases as agency staff casual workers and mariners for anyone who thinks it unlikely that an employer would miss this vital information i am proof that underpayments can and do happen having noticed that my own smp didnt include an annual pay rise effective from february this year i queried the amount and discovered that my employers payroll company had used the hmrc calculator to arrive at my erroneous smp figure shortchanging me by about this londonbased company is now concerned enough to review every smp calculation it has provided to clients over the past year knowing there will probably be other mistakes hmrc insists it would be impossible to set up the smp calculator to take pay rises into account and points out that no other agency has managed to do so it also suggests that employers seeking information on this subject should contact the department of work and pensions which sets policy on smp the dwp website under the advisers section helpfully gives chapter and verse on the ecj ruling and its application but we would refer employers looking for information on smp to the department of trade and industry says a spokesman the dti does indeed provide smp information to employers distributed to employers through acas and the confederation of british industry but its leaflet on employees maternity rights dates from and even the more uptodate website fails to mention the crucial payrise ruling but this doesnt matter because employers get their information on how to calculate smp from hmrc not from us says a spokesman so its back to square one the good news is that any woman who received smp during the past year and thinks she might have been underpaid can request that her employer recalculate payment due taking any relevant pay rise into account and subsequently claim any discrepancy women who did not qualify for smp because their earnings were too low but who would have qualified had the pay rise been included in the smp calculation can also claim the difference between the smp that should have been paid and the maternity allowance they received the ecjs ruling was not intended to be retrospective so women who took maternity leave before april will not be automatically covered but the dwp says any woman who took maternity leave can make a claim for arrears within six years of smp being paid be warned though that employers are obliged to keep smp records for three years only if your employer no longer has records of what was paid during your smp period the burden of proving underpayment will fall on you know your rights all pregnant women are entitled to paid time off for antenatal care including parenting and relaxation classes they are also entitled to weeks ordinary maternity leave irrespective of how long they have worked for their employer any woman who has worked for her employer continuously for at least weeks can further claim up to weeks additional maternity leave all new mothers must take at least two weeks maternity leave following the birth of their baby smp is payable for up to weeks to women who have been employed by their employer for at least weeks up to and including their qualifying week th week before the week in which the baby is due and who earn at least as much as the lower earnings limit for national insurance women who dont qualify for smp may qualify for maternity allowance instead during ordinary maternity leave employment is considered to be continuous so employees can still claim their usual annual leave and their pension entitlements are unaffected women returning to the workplace are entitled to request flexible working arrangements and employers are obliged to seriously consider these requests for more information on maternity rights and benefits see wwwtigergovuk

text: clare dyer rightly highlights the concern that services for complainants of sexual assault are becoming increasingly disparate across the uk with many police forces outsourcing these services to commercial companies that employ overseas doctors with little experience or commitment to the work evidencegathering in rape cases in crisis doctors warn may the new faculty of forensic and legal medicine which has been established by the royal college of physicians shares this concern although the number of reported rapes represents only a tiny proportion of all recorded crimes the severity of its impact on victims and the fear of the crime give it major importance within the criminal justice system the marked decline in the percentage of successful prosecutions for rape offences which in the uk has dropped from in to in is therefore a cause for serious concern while there are many causes for the unacceptably high attrition rates one of these is unquestionably the variable quality of medical evidence in court complainants of sexual assault are entitled to be examined by a forensic practitioner with the specialist knowledge skills and attitudes to gather evidence objectively impartially and with compassion anything less than this can rightly be considered further abuse it is clearly unacceptable for a complainant to be examined by a doctor whose command of english is so poor that he can communicate with neither the complainant nor the jury as dyer reported nor can it be right that two adolescent girls should be examined by a locum doctor who normally works as an orthopaedic registrar and who has no theoretical or practical experience of dealing with victims of sexual assaults but not only must doctors be competent to examine complainants of sexual assault they must also have the training and experience to understand the pitfalls of giving expert evidence in court and be able to express highquality opinions that are evidencebased and free of dogma clearly doctors also need to be in this country and not their homelands in order to give evidence at present there is no formal specialist recognition within the medical establishment for those who practise forensic and legal medicine such as forensic physicians who examine rape victims key objectives for our faculty are to obtain such recognition and ensure the highest professional standards of competence and ethical integrity it must become unacceptable for outsourced companies to provide services without appropriate specialist support the home office in recognising the importance of improving forensic and healthcare provision to the police service has provided us with support and resources it is to be hoped that those police forces which outsource forensic medical services share these views and ensure that providers employ doctors with the appropriate expertise and experience if not there is a real danger of the innocent being convicted and the guilty going free dr guy a new sexual manifesto a way to counter the oversexualisation of modern culture a female audiencemember put forward the thesis that raunch culture described by writer ariel levy in her book female chauvinist pigs as the sudden popularity for lap dancers pole dancing and leering and beering among women was all mens fault it was a symptom of our patriarchal society and mens rampant desire for female flesh was to blame if men were not in the market for these degrading images of women they wouldnt exist in the first place sex sells because its what men want women dress in short skirts because its what men want women go to lapdancing clubs because it is a place men like to go in raunch culture liberation and empowerment for women involves behaving like a man but who decided that these are the only types of sexuality that men are interested in who decided that behaving like a man involves going to lapdancing clubs or salivating over porn stars who decided that men are all beholden to the fantasy world of boobs and beer with an unstoppable desire for sexual prowess the current sexual climate caricatures mens sexuality and damages men the blame for this lies in many places but nowhere is the roots of this problem clearer than in the pernicious world of lad culture heres a phenomenon that through its media the lad magazine supposedly gives young men the confidence they need an insight into the skills for a successful romantic life and an understanding of what women find attractive but in reality these magazines simply try to convince men that their lives are somehow filled with grave problems your job is not exciting enough you dont know the right things to say you certainly dont dress well enough and certainly you dont know how to attract women fortunately the same magazines can give you all the answers tips on how to dress what to drink what aftershave to splash on how to behave if you want women to think you are a real man lad culture not only promotes the unashamed pursuit of women as the only way to prove yourself as a man it also distorts the image young men have of themselves lad culture wants men to internalise this simple message you are worthless is it this behaviour and the subsequent caricature of sexuality that the fans of raunch culture want to emulate any new sexual manifesto has to tackle this gross distortion of masculinity women have their own task to reclaim feminism from those who think that lap dancing is empowerment and liberation men have a pressing task too to break out of the straitjacket that lad culture has locked us into those of us offended by the objectification of male sexuality must stand up and shout just as loudly as the proponents of lad culture that men should never have to bow down to the rules and ideals set down by magazines that want nothing from us but our money and dignity lynne segal a professor psychology and gender studies at birkbeck college and a panelist at last nights debate said that feminists have been here at the point of campaigning against the gross oversexualisation of society in the s just before their attempts to ban pornography but somehow other issues took over and their concerns over the sexualisation were sidelined whats to say this will not happen again simply blaming men for the problem is too easy too crass the answer must be to look at text: the number of dads making a contribution to childcare has increased eightfold in the last generation say new figures from the equal opportunities commission yet in most relationships its still the woman who takes on the caring responsibilities when a couple have kids and for many mums that means accepting deadend lowskilled roles because theyre the only ones that let them work flexibly mothers are often forced to work at lower levels than theyre qualified for says marion davies of loneparent charity one plus there are situations where they go for employment because its flexible rather than because its suitable she explains a lot of lone parents will do this because they want to get back into the labour market and then theres a lot of frustration because they cant move forward they hope theyll get a better job eventually but they can be waiting a long time just under half of all jobs in retail for instance are filled by women working parttime these positions were created specifically to attract female workers but jobs where women have some flexibility still tend to be concentrated in the lower grades of the industry says usdaw the union for shopworkers which is campaigning to raise the status of parttime work though its supporting parents and carers campaign theres an unwritten requirement that middle and senior jobs have to be done on a fulltime basis and over long working hours says the unions equalities officer jo bird but there is a more subtle thing going on too an assumption that because jobs are parttime the people who do them arent committed and dont really have any skills and ive had women tell me that theyve been going through the management training process but as soon as they get pregnant theres an assumption that theyre not committed and wont be aiming for management any more but can highly responsible senior jobs be done flexibly around family commitments according to carol savage chief executive and founder of flexecutive which advises on parttime working the answer is a qualified yes i believe you can do every job on a flexible basis it just depends on the kind of flexibility youre talking about receptionists for instance cant work at home but you can jobshare that position she says if you can only do five hours in the middle of the day then i think thats the hardest to make work in a managerial role the easiest way for mums to work at a senior level is to do two or three full days rather than am to pm over five days at usdaw jo bird wryly notes that since men have started asking for more flexibility in their working conditions things have gradually started to get better for women too its about redesigning jobs through a creative approach to work dawn gascoigne is a franchisee and independent travel consultant for travel counsellors mum to two young girls she built up years experience in the travel business working for thomas cook but left months ago to set up on her own when she realised that while the company would allow her to work parttime it would not consider a more flexible approach to managing her working hours being the manager of a whole travel agency means that everything is solely your responsibility and i took that very seriously indeed if anything went wrong on my day off id forfeit the time and go in i didnt want to have to do that with a growing family so i went back as a parttime sales consultant on less than half my salary it was mostly fine at first but when you have children things do come up and if you cant work with your employer around them it can get stressful i felt strongly that some of my work could be done remotely and i literally begged thomas cook to let me work evenings at home but they said theyd trialled it before and it hadnt worked i had to accept that despite being sure i could manage it fine i know now through being an independent consultant for travel counsellors that it does work very well for my clients and there is a place in this highly competitive market for it it was such a little thing that made me realise that if i couldnt work flexibly in a high street agency i had to find a way to do it for myself id not been able to get time off to see my daughter run in a pancake day race i decided that my family needed the flexibility of me being able to work around these things it was a risk to go selfemployed because its all on commission but now i can do evenings when the girls are in bed and hours in the day when theyre at school i dont very often work at weekends compared with the high street agencies that dictate that you have to but when you have a family weekends are very precious im four times better off now than i was before and with less stress i do think it is possible to have children and to stay senior but if your child is sick or you have a pancake day to go to thats frowned upon and that causes stress if you want a balance that kind of work doesnt offer it at the moment and its a shame because there are a huge number of mums with huge amounts of experience and dedication but who just cant do the all or nothing karen coles from south wales had her five children over an year period before deciding last autumn that she wanted to enter the world of work she began with two weeks of work experience through the marks amp start scheme a community initiative run by marks amp spencer to support people who face barriers of various kinds in getting a job the company says that it is committed to offering flexible working at all levels id really wanted to go back to work for a while but i just felt worthless and to tell you the truth i was scared of going into a workplace the first day i went in i was so anxious i didnt think i could face going back i was so nervous of meeting new people i did a placement first where they team you up with a buddy who helps you through it i did feel a bit shaky but as the two weeks on i got more confident at the end i was feeling really good like i was worth something so i applied for a temporary job behind a till with hours from ampm i got that job and did it for six months theyve just taken me on permanent which feels great i do shifts working pmpm for four days a week and my eldest boy whos looks after the littler ones im better off now than i was on benefit probably by about or a week i feel times better about myself too and the kids are proud of me i think until my youngest is at school im happy to work these hours but i know at marks amp spencer that you can move up and be a line manager or a trainer and still work parttime or do restricted hours while earning more in a better job elise danson name changed has a yearold son and works parttime in an amusement arcade she has just had to turn down a promotion because of the working hours it would have required id left one job already because of the unreasonable hours they ended up wanting me to do i was the supervisor of the arcade in that job but now im a cashier and the money isnt nearly as good i work four hours a day now to fit in with getting my boy to school id been at this new job just a few weeks when they offered me the chance of being manageress the pay was a lot better probably a week more and that kind of money would make a big difference to us i could improve a lot of things on that wage but it meant working long shifts four days a week and i just couldnt this industry doesnt really let you work parttime in that sort of job to be honest i think getting a betterpaid job on parttime hours is just going to be one of those impossible things

text: two us researchers from the universities of florida international and miami finley and schwartz have redone parsons and bales famous s study on fatherhood volume no of psychology of men and masculinity the outcome of the revisit is surprising in that it is surprisingly similar to the outcome years ago examining the characterisation of the fathering role parsons and bales found this centred on socalled instrumental functions that is fathering was more about providing income protection and discipline than it was about expressive functions these the more emotional aspects of caregiving were found to be largely motherly functions the original study covered an ethnically diverse sample of american students from both divorced and intact families the aim was to gauge the role their fathers had played in their upbringing using a similarly diverse sample finley and schwartzs research shows that years later despite huge societal change little has altered in the nature of fathering inherent in the instrumental role is less presence in the daily life of the child so it is surprising considering womens hugely increased participation in the workforce since the s that there has apparently been so little change in the level of expressive parenting among fathers presumably there has been a commensurate significant increase in mothers instrumental function relating to income that there has not been more of a shift in the share of emotional parenting is odd and worrying if as seems likely conclusions can be drawn about british fathers from this study perhaps the governments recent claim of a sea change among young fathers accompanying the dfess daddy packs is a misreading of the true situation
