text: an obsession with the stripped self is sold today as semaphoring liberated female sexuality writes angela phillips there is nothing in these vapid air brushed pictures that says anything about female desire she argues they are all about male desire desire or power the new debate about raunch culture and its bed partner a sexualised consumerism apparently determined to turn tots into spendthrift tarts how many playboy pencil cases pole dancing classes and pushup bras does a girl small medium or large actually need is paradoxically so oldfashioned old because no matter how much women revealing all believe they are behaving of their own free will contrary to what ariel levy argues they are still imprisoned in a cage constructed by the patriarchy one which ironically also imprisons many men just as surely as it constrained in different ways their virginal straightlaced sisters a hundred years ago the fact that some today cant see the bars isnt anyones fault but it does tell us that without an active sense of vigilance and the ability to analyse how and why female selfconsciousness has been exploited for centuries then feminism is easily reduced to an elegy on a gstring and the cheap and illusionary thrill of girls behaving badly ways of seeing was written by john berger years ago the ways we see things he pointed out is affected by what we see and what we know he described a woman in vanity a painting by the th century artist hans meling on the surface she fulfils all the criteria that according to writer ariel levy merit the label female chauvinist pig defined as women who make sex objects of other women and themselves hans memlings woman stands brazenly and unabashedly naked in the middle of a field how raunchy is that shorn of pubic hair a medieval brazilian admiring herself in a mirror how bold can you go then berger points out that at that time the pubic hair was shorn by male artists because it denoted potency and passion they men who paid for these paintings wanted women supine submissive and childlike any parallels with the huge surge in interest in internet child pornography women are there to feed an appetite not have one of their own berger wrote the mirror often used in art as the symbol of female vanity underlining a womans selfconsciousness and the importance of beauty rather than brains also reminded the world of a womans place in it the real function of the mirror was to make woman connive in treating herself as first and foremost a sight berger explains in an oftenrepeated quote he says men act and women appear men look at women women watch themselves being looked at this determines not only most relations between men and women but also the relation of women to themselves if that doesnt ring any bells then perhaps the following might to be born a woman berger suggested is to be born into an allotted and confined space into the keeping of men the social presence of women has developed as a result of their ingenuity in living under such tutelage within such a limited space from earliest childhood she has been and persuaded to survey herself continually all of which can be witnessed daily on what is at present two highly visible allotted and confined spaces namely the big brother house overflowing with females pretending to be comfortable in their cosmetically acquired skin but failing with various degrees of misery and the daily trouping of the colour performed by the wags wives and girlfriends of the english football team in germany while the men and thousands of envious twentysomething females watch of course the position of women has changed but conditioning runs deep and we are a time of transition young women may act sexy but how many really feel it without the benefit of booze so instead of genuinely developing their own appetites they opt for burlesque the debate about female sexual exhibitionism and what it signals is based on a couple of assumptions its what all men want and most younger women participate in it neither is true change and progress is a messy business three steps forward two back three and a half forward so while many females my say they think they are too fat too flawed too imperfect they get on with their lives for all anyone knows having deeply satisfying erotic encounters happily with strangers of even monogamously with their partner of years without the paraphernalia of raunch of course there are also men out there too who are interested in female desire as apposed to what they think females desire falsely tutored by nuts and jordan in poses caught in a time warp somewhere in the s men who know that sex is all in the head and that how you see women influences how you treat them cause for optimism also comes from older women reared during years when sex was deemed dirty many say their sex lives have never been better perhaps because they have begun to step outside their allotted space lost their selfconsciousness and like some men developed an appetite of their own angela phillips rightly describes how teenagers are having sex younger and often regret it and that sex education in british schools is still based too much on sex and not enough on an education in selfconfidence mutual respect and relationships yet school isnt the only source of information research shows a large proportion of teenagers do have a strong connection with their parents and can and do talk about emotions and handle their relationships with surprising maturity even those teenage girls who to quote angela say innit womens equality or the lack of it as reflected in pay who does what in the home and who runs the establishment remains a goal not a reality in the uk and is virtually nonexistent in the developing world where raunchiness of course in the shape of sex tourism is a major industry in that context the question of whether a woman pole dances or not narrows the vision we cant have social justice so well have sex publicly instead and pretend its revolution on the other hand perhaps this debate inadequate as it is may after all help to spark our awareness of how much is being corroded in the name of counterfeit sexual liberation choice and profit

text: in after six years of researching writing and updating a book called the facts of rape i decided i was never going to tackle anything again that i couldnt joke about but years on with abysmal conviction rates for rape again in the news i was struck by a shocking comparison in cases of rape were recorded by police in england and wales the same year men either admitted they were guilty or were found guilty of the crime between april and march the total number of rapes of women by men recorded by police in england and wales was in just either admitted the crime or were subsequently found guilty of it thats over more reported crimes than in but only a few hundred more convictions in one in three reported rapes ended in convictions in one in not only were the figures astonishing they were depressing beyond belief did they mean rape was out of control and the system even less equipped to deal with it or that the thousands of women who wouldnt have reported the crime in were now reporting it but were even less likely to see their assailants punished the answer had to lie somewhere in the chain of events between the crime and the jury returning its verdict the most obvious place to start looking for it was the crown court on a horrible monday in december last year i went to southwark south london in search of a trial where the complainant and the defendant were known to each other and where the case hinged on the issue of her consent these are the critical features in the vast majority of rape allegations and years ago they were also the reasons most never got to court or if they did were most likely to end in an acquittal my plan was to work backwards to use the trial as a springboard into the system to see exactly what was happening to create the awful state of affairs suggested by the statistics i chose court only because it was a single defendant and the charge was rape this is the story of an allegation made on april and its outcome nine months later im calling the complainant a and the man she accused b im not naming the barristers or judge either because they asked me not to april was a thursday some time between am and am b who is in his mids and weighs stone dragged a in her late s and nine stone up the stairs of her house in south london to her bedroom on the first floor he pushed her inside and locked the door she pleaded with him she said she had her period but b pushed her back on to the bed pulled her pyjama bottoms off then got on top of her a struggled to free herself she said she would scream and other people in the house would hear her but b put a pillow over her face and said if she didnt shut up hed kill her when he had finished he ran out of the house jumped into his car and sped away a went down to the kitchen found her phone then went back to the living room and sat on the settee she hadnt been able to speak when a lodger in the kitchen had asked her if she was ok the phone rang her nephew who lived nearby with his girlfriend had heard the sound of the car and looked out of his window aware that a was frightened of b he wanted to know if she was all right she told him b had raped her he arrived at the house within minutes and then fetched his girlfriends mother mrs c who also lived nearby she called the police five hours later b was arrested on the building site where he was working he agreed he and a had had sex she had consented to it he said he had gone to the house having telephoned in advance to collect some tools she had made him a cup of tea he had kissed her and she hadnt objected she had suggested they go upstairs to talk so they wouldnt wake anyone else in the house they had started to have sex but stopped because she was having a period hed left in a hurry because he was late for work and that was why she was angry until two weeks previously a and b had lived as man and wife they had been partners for years she had thrown him out after he had made sexual advances towards one of their lodgers and she didnt want him back now here they were in southwark crown court in front of a jury of eight men and four women whose job it was to decide if he was the rapist she said he was and there i was thinking forget it it was her word against his there was no physical evidence of injury or of resistance they had had consensual sex weeks earlier and probability wasnt going to come into it the jury would have to be sure the judge would tell them both defence and prosecuting counsel would tell them that if they werent sure b was guilty they must acquit him in the case wouldnt even have got to court rape between a husband and wife wasnt a crime until even if they had had no prior sexual relationship it is doubtful the police would have prosecuted because juries were warned not to convict on a complainants uncorroborated evidence it seemed to me a miracle that a was in the courtroom at all even if the british crime survey found that of rapists were current or former partners or boyfriends of victims but it soon became clear that both the investigative and legal processes were infinitely kinder to the victim than they had been in the corroboration requirement had been dropped in section of the youth justice and criminal evidence act of had outlawed the cynical use of a complainants sexual history although this week a report sponsored by the home office found this still occurs and the sexual offences act had addressed the problems of consent both what it was and what a reasonable belief in it might be according to a crown prosecution service directive a person consents if he or she agrees by choice to the sexual activity and has the freedom and capacity to make that choice all the circumstances at the time of the offence will be looked at in determining whether the defendant is reasonable in believing the complainant consented people will be considered most unlikely to have agreed to sexual activity if they were subject to threats or fear of serious harm unconscious drugged abducted or unable to communicate because of a physical disability as argument was that she had had sex with b because she was terrified and he had persisted despite her protests bs was that he had had no reason to believe a wasnt consenting the prosecuting barrister established the facts in his opening address which was based on as videotaped interview with a sexual offences investigative techniques soit officer on the day she made the allegation soits were introduced to sexual offence investigations by londons metropolitan police as part persuade the jury at an initial trial in july they had failed to reach a verdict so the judge had ordered a retrial this is why everyone was back in court in december the fact that a had had the strength to continue was a tribute to the way in which her case had been handled i thought but it was clear that this case was far from typical di paul meaden head of the greenwich sapphire unit talked me through a snapshot of rape allegations made to the met during april and may and where they stood by the following september of allegations made one of which was as were classified as crimes rest part of the problem in detection di meaden says is the number of cases involving drink a number of women who report crimes have a very limited memory of what happened because they were so drunk text: we need a new sexual manifesto that much is clear the objectification of womens bodies the corporate commitment to sex sells the pornification of the media and advertising that has even managed to seep into our individual sexual urges is depressing in its omnipotence in todays g the feminist writer ariel levy defends her use of the term female chauvinist pigs to describe the many women who not only accept this hypersexualised culture but actively promote and engage in it in their quest for a barbieinspired body in their visits to strip clubs in their lapdancing routines sure female chauvinist pigs isnt the perfect phrase to describe these women implying as it does an attack on women supposedly in need of defence but im inclined to think that this is the least of our worries whatever you call it lets say we are agreed that on the level of identification at least there is a problem as angela phillips argues on comment is free today young people grasping at notions of adulthood have always been easily influenced by what is around them is it any surprise that teenagers are having sex earlier when sex is all they see nevertheless some people will persist in interpreting this raunch culture as a form of female sexual freedom and evidence that we have won the sex war levy asks however when did we win the war we dont have equal pay for equal work we dont have equal representation in government so when exactly did we win we didnt win but that doesnt mean we have stopped trying and amid all this fighting talk it is dangerous to forget the actual fight the f word may have fallen out of fashion we are told with just one british female in four calling herself a feminist but last weekend in a small stuffy room in the basement of the central hall in westminster the existence not just of feminism but of ripples of its third wave was undeniable young and old female and male feminists representing different but complementary sets of beliefs gathered together at the compass conference for a seminar hosted by the gender equality campaign organisation the fawcett society entitled is this feminisms third wave the panel consisting of the founder of thefwordorguk catherine redfern the writer natasha walter and the academic haleh afshar sparked a dynamic and inspiring debate that left many of the other duller less wellattended seminars that day in the shade while the growing problem of our raunch culture was easily identified in a schoolteachers tale of her female pupils desperate to adorn themselves with pink in the women who only felt successful and equal if they conformed to sexual stereotypes the seminar floundered when coming up with ways to tackle it for how can you persuade a boy surrounded by pornographic images of women that he must not harass a woman on the street that a woman who wears a short skirt is not asking to be raped how can we strike a balance between individual sexual liberation and the mass marketisation of an industry that makes a ton of money trading on female body parts in essence how can you change society and bring about a cultural shift levy herself has disappointingly opted out of the challenge i am a writer not an activist she says i agree with her interviewer kira cochrane thats a pity what can written words on their own really achieve but in britain there is action as well as words small steps to challenge culture sexism are being made feminist blogs and online forums are flourishing fawcetts membership is surging and redfern spoke inspiringly of a range of grassroots activism lobbying and networking by young feminists across the county the anecdotes were incredibly heartening of local reclaim the night marches of brave individual attempts to challenge sexual stereotypes of consciousnessraising and above all of a genuine desire to find ways to tackle this sexual saturation but can such activities reach their potential without a national movement for change without someone willing to stand up and spearhead a highprofile campaign maybe monday nights guardian debate a new sexual manifesto will provide some more answers for a unified way forward is legislation the key it has been tried before when the eu proposed banning degrading images of women in the media or do we need a more longterm agenda in our schools in the media in our newsagents in individual women and men during saturdays seminar afshar warned that evidence of feminisms vibrant and political third wave is now easier to locate in the developing world than it is in the west in libya women tell afshar that western feminism is rubbish its all about taking your knickers down they say if this is really the reputation of our womens rights movement abroad if british women really are entering a dead end of passion and sexual enjoyment that simply conforms to tired and hugely unerotic stereotypes of sex and relationships then it is time we did something concrete about it there is hope for change there was a real energy in the room on saturday busy and bursting with ideas it felt like something was happening and about time too now we need action lets write that manifesto

text: smoking behind the bike sheds snogging in the park scrawling graffiti on walls wearing clothes your mother hates reading stuff that you shouldnt looking at pictures that are banned and drinking until you throw up are nothing new kids everywhere use their teenage years to try out the things that to them mean adulthood in homes and schools everywhere adults try variously to forbid them or teach them why it might not be such a good idea to copy their very worst excesses growing up is partly about internalising the boundaries the adult world sets and partly about setting them down somewhere new over the last years the boundaries for young women have shifted from the hedge around the garden to the far horizon when i was at school it was a standard assumption that girls couldnt do maths might faint at the sight of blood and could not run anything more taxing than a vicarage tea party change was not imposed on them by adults they fought for it they wrestled with tough angry privileged men who hung on and defended their right to rule women who fought were ridiculed and abused and the most powerful tool in that armoury then as now was to attack their confidence in their sexual attractiveness then as now when a man feels threatened by a woman he denounces her as ugly unsexy someone he wouldnt want to sleep with it is a great strategy to feel undesired and undesirable is not something the average young woman finds easy to deal with whatever else might be won the right to equal pay equal opportunity to join clubs and take our place in ruling the world few heterosexual women then or now were willing to risk the loss of male desire it is that fear more than anything else that sets women against each other those who denounced feminism or started every possibly threatening sentence with the words i am not a feminist but were doing it not because they thought women shouldnt have these things but because they feared male rejection if they identified with the cause young women today have aspirations for themselves that are beyond the wildest dreams of their feminist mothers and grandmothers but that fear of male sexual rejection has not gone away indeed as women have gained power the fear of male rejection seems to have reached epic proportions and always quick to spot a trend the media has picked up on this anxiety and mercilessly exploited it yearolds learn about relationships from sex and the city and desperate housewives and then wear clothes on the street that would once have had them arrested students send pictures of their breasts to nuts magazine just for the buzz of it women who would once have allowed their postnatal tummies to sag gently are desperately starving themselves back into their jeans so that they can be yummy mummies like the celebrities they see in hello magazine those same mothers buy their prepubescent children thongs and dresses with playboy symbols some people suggest that this obsession with the self is actually about a new and more liberated sexuality that all this display is evidence that women are coming out of their closeted world and learning to enjoy their bodies the evidence suggests that this is not the case certainly young women are learning that sexual display attracts male attention the last figures from the national sex and lifestyle survey natsal show that the average age of first intercourse dropped a year in a decade but every study also shows that earlier isnt better there is a very high level of regret among those who have sex under the age of and women are twice as likely as men to regret their first experience and three times as likely to report being the less willing partner this sense of being continually on display up there on the shelves plastered over the billboards smeared over the morning newspaper is not liberation it is sending out a message to young women that in order to be loved it is necessary to be perfect and always available there is nothing in these vapid airbrushed pictures that says anything at all about female desire they are all about male desire these are women who are there to satisfy men not themselves the saddest thing of all is the realisation as ariel levy points out in g today that it is often women not men who have put those pictures there the women who do it are quite literally cashing in on the exploitation and unhappiness of millions of teenage girls who grow up thinking that this is what it means to be a woman and to be desired by men display may be a part of sex for some women it certainly isnt all there is for all women our teens are now the most sexually experienced in europe they are probably also the most confused where other countries treat sex and relationships as a part of education and talk about such things the whole way through school our schools are held in check by a fringe group of religious nutters with a direct line to almost every national newspaper editor the very same newspapers that follow the antics of big brother and pick apart the appearance of every female who sticks her nose above the parapet also denounce any attempt to make sex and relationship education a serious part of the curriculum with headlines such as sex lessons for fiveyearolds while young people are denied the opportunity to discuss their feelings and desires with properly trained responsible adults they are exposed on a daily basis to tv programmes that tell them it is normal to ask for breast implants for their th birthday or to get an extreme makeover if they want to be loved young people will learn how to be adults whichever way they can if we leave the job to the media companies then we shouldnt be shocked that quite a lot of them learn that it is just normally naughty for girls of to get drunk and have sex they may not remember much about it and they almost certainly didnt enjoy it but that is after all what adults do innit our generation may have taught our daughters to be clever and brave but we dont seem to have taught them how to be happy they will have to move that boundary for themselves fortunately moving boundaries is what young people are good at angela phillips will be giving a paper on this subject on thursday at the goldsmiths college seminar the word girl in a global frame ariel levy will be speaking at a guardian debate on raunch culture at pm on monday june at the oliver thompson lecture theatre city university her book female chauvinist pigs women and the rise of raunch culture is available now

text: we are never told her name none of the soldiers would have been interested in such niceties the only considerations were that she was vietnamese and a virgin it was like an animal pack one of the participants recalled we just stood in line and we screwed her suddenly unexpectedly the unnamed woman turned towards him why are you doing this to me she said in english why whether in vietnam iraq or cornwall rape destroys the victims trust in the world the realisation that other individuals are impervious to ones suffering never wanes yet violent sexuality is alarmingly common last year over women in britain reported being raped this statistic ignores the fact that most rapes are never spoken about according to the british crime survey only one in six rapes is reported to the police why is rape so common it is hard to avoid the conclusion that the fusion of aggression and sexuality appeals to some men it is striking how frequently rapists situate their abuses in a framework associated with dating culture bizarrely employing the language of romance in the midst of the assault when confronted with evidence of pain they either eroticise it or demand a simulation of gratification from their victims even more disturbingly rapists frequently insist that they not their victims are traumatised by the assault during the vietnam war for instance the diagnosis of posttraumatic stress disorder was given to servicemen who had suffered the trauma of raping other individuals today the psychological stress of military service is being used to justify the sexual torture that took place in abu ghraib and elsewhere sympathy for the abuser is not restricted to war zones in britain today there is considerable scepticism expressed towards women who accuse men of rape in fact false accusations are less common in rape than in other criminal cases but any woman with a slightly adventurous history or hailing from a powerless group is normally right to think that making a complaint is not worthwhile in the s around one third of reported rape cases ended in convictions this dropped to around one quarter by the s today only of rapes reported to the police end up with a conviction and in gloucestershire suffolk and cambridgeshire only two men are convicted for every women who report being raped are we to believe that women in these counties are particularly prone to lying about rape of course no one is denying that the justice system has improved the times when judges could joke about the colour of a victims knickers are over however the gap between law in books and law in practice is still wide informal norms of case processing judgment and sentencing have remained substantially unchanged legal decisions continue to be profoundly affected by assumptions about what constitutes real rape it is encouraging therefore to hear the sentencing guidelines council insisting last week that date rape and rape within marriage should be treated as severely as rape by a stranger the council is calling for judges to impose tougher prison sentences yet rape myths are still pervasive in particular the belief that victims somehow brought it on themselves an icm poll last year found that one in three people believed that women who acted flirtatiously were partially or totally responsible if they ended up being raped and one in four believed the same for women who wore sexy clothes both men and women proved willing to blame the victim in other areas debate about rape is silenced some forms of sexual abuse remain so taboo that victims have great difficulty reporting them forced sex within marriage is hardly unusual for instance the rape of men has also remained out of bounds in the rape debates the gay community is reluctant to discuss the extent of the problem perhaps legitimately fearing its link to a homophobic agenda the abuse of men by women is another deadly secret the tired mantra of the s according to which all men are rapists rape fantasists or beneficiaries of a rape culture has become mere wishful thinking in the face of what happened at abu ghraib not confronting these myths is bad for all of us the politics of sexual pleasure has been displaced into the politics of sexual fear such negative politics leaves no room for anything save the paradox of telling women and other potential victims that they need to purchase freedom by investing in deadbolt locks as we reduce tolerance for displays of macho sexual aggression in daily life we need to educate men into positive male erotics finally victims of abuse too often feel that they are to blame for their victimisation if we are to imagine a world without the spectre of sexual violence hanging over us perpetrators have to be held fully accountable for their deeds too many have been getting away with rape we cannot tolerate it any longer joanna bourke is professor of history at birkbeck college her book on rapists is published next year telly without finding bad girls or the the l word i have left the ranks of my former sisterhood and betrayed them after years of being in relationships with women why have i returned to as my boyfriend likes to tease the true faith heterosexuality the answer confuses me in fact it confuses most people i hear from the gay gossip mill that many of the lesbian elite including my ex who left me for a yearold have been saying i was never actually gay funny my girlfriends never said that in bed what does that do to my nomination for a lambda literary award and my commentaries on gay marriage for nprs all things considered my mother compares lesbianism with my other phase vegetarianism which lasted over a decade too you know bounced over to heterosexuality to see if women were faring any better than years ago when i got fed up with the straight scene and men in general perhaps i should have just given up on the man who broke my heart but instead i tossed out the whole gender and developed an appreciation for girls all i know is that as a former vegetarian i discovered my body craves steak as a former lesbian i have discovered similar cravings at the same time im really glad i didnt spend the last years living a traditional life i had a terrible track record with men when i finally decided to give them up for lent becoming a lesbian was a logical decision men are only per cent of the population so why limit myself i left the straight world behind and discovered that i could have much healthier relationships with women the sex was good too of course as i found out theres not a whole lot of difference between men and women in the heartbreaking department the confusion comes from people wondering how i can go from sex with men to sex with women without pause or ponder its not difficult i know the mystery is what girls do in bed lets just say we do everything everyone else does we just do it longer women are always ready to pop if you know what buttons to press maybe i got fed up with men because none knew how to press the right buttons granted i didnt know much about my buttons before i became a lesbian but thats whats great about being gay women know about women and everything your mother wouldnt tell you your girlfriend will so why would i leave the isle of lesbos for the promised land of pecs i mean women are soft and cuddly they understand all about pmt men are hard they cringe when you get that glazed pmt gaze and make plans to go on holiday with the lads they dont say things like did you take your primrose oil kissing a man who hasnt shaved is like kissing a brillo pad most do not realise that women dont need an intermission we are the second and third act the standing ovation and the curtain call trembling in the wings afterward however there are things about men that a lesbian like me is learning to appreciate for instance im the only one in the house with pmt thank god and im the only one in bed having layer upon layer of pleasure women are exhausting its also a relief to be sassy and not hurt his feelings he likes my acerbic wit while i always seemed to be ruffling my exs feathers he also cooks the man who seduced me or who i seduced were still debating this issue is british that made a difference he can quote shakespeare and monty python and has that sexy accent too british men seem to be more sensitive than american men they can discuss things other than football except during the world cup the champions league the fa cup and when i was going through a rough patch he helped me through it as a writer too he offered me a refuge through weekly emails discussing everything from the lambing season to his broken heart it had been a lifelong dream of mine to attend the hayonwye literary festival and in the midst of my divorce no we werent really married because in the land of the free gays still cant marry the man i would eventually seduce invited me to hay for tea it was not a comeon how could it be i was gay or was i tea in wales sounded like an excellent idea though i admit i was more interested in a properly poured guinness anyway i put in a travel requisition to the college where i teach creative writing and the next thing i knew i was being sent to hayonwye for professional development you can pick up girls and i can pick up girls james suggested in his email personally i couldnt wait to be developed professionally an unshaven james dressed as casually as any american picked me up in abergavenny and an hour later we were sitting outside his cottage having a glass of wine and talking about our divorces just like we had been talking about them through emails for the past few months the demise of our year relationships and former lives hung heavy in the warm spring air but the anticipation of new possibilities lingered on the breeze the next day the festival began and i found myself swept up in hay fever i felt like i had been living outside my body for months but surrounded by book lovers authors and pimms i felt fully present and accounted for i hadnt laughed in months and now i couldnt stop i met wonderful people in the pubs and queues i felt intoxicated by the mere presence of my host after my ex left me i thought i should try men again and james was the perfect guinea pig he knew my story so if it was a miserable experience he wouldnt take it personally and we could laugh it off and still be friends still i hadnt made up my mind so i maintained professional distance i mean i couldnt very well stand in the green room talking with stephen fry about gay marriage and think about shagging james could i but i was what the hell was going on i hadnt been attracted to men for years ok ive always had a thing for biceps but women can with editors and drinking cheap champagne there was an afterhours party at whitney court but james couldnt find any girls to pick up and neither could i it was late or early depending on how you turn the world the sky shifted from black to indigo as we sped through the lanes back to his cottage madeleine peyroux sang dance me to the end of love in the living room we kissed like friends who want to be naughty birds started to chirp youre not going to get weird on me are you he asked i wasnt planning on it are you i quipped we write good dialogue for the next week the precoital line seemed to be not those damn birds again i dont think either of us had stayed up so late for so many consecutive nights in years we danced to elvis costello jools holland neither james nor i had danced in years that was when things started to shift instead of wondering what i was doing with a man i started wondering why i had spent years with someone who didnt like to dance party socialise the list went on after i returned home our relationship seemed to take a more literary bent pun intended we began to correspond as the fictitious characters out of an ian fleming novel no james is not really his name but it seemed an appropriate response when he said youre quite a girl pussy with the same long accent on the u that sean connery made so famous we have quite a lot in common too i know what he likes in women lots of them hes been very honest about his penchant for the ladies which is why he was an especially good candidate for my experiment dont be surprised if you call some day and a woman answers the phone he warned me dont be surprised if you call me and a woman answers the phone too i had thought that hayonwye would be like las vegas what you do there stays there it was safe and far away from my real life i didnt want a relationship or anything else complicated and i certainly didnt want to have to go home and inform the lesbian community that i was no longer a member of americas disenfranchised class the thing is i went back to hay twice more last year and at quiz night in hay this past december we won golden tickets to this years festival england has gotten under my skin and despite pussy galores imperviousness this james has gotten under my skin as well he has a prose style to make any literary lesbian swoon is it others who feel the need to define me or me who feels the need to define myself my real friends gay and straight alike are happy im happy they dont care what or whom i do as long as im enjoying my life theyre just glad im not calling up sobbing any more did i realise that women can break my heart just as easily as men and decide to widen the playing field to include everyone or is it more important who a person is on the inside than their gender maybe it was all those bloody bookshops in hay that made me swoon but i think it was more than that because im still swooning maybe i really like men maybe i just like james gay or straight or bi does it really matter ok hes told me id better not leave him for a woman which from a womaniser is pretty funny the next time we walked the hallowed streets of hayonwye i was silently commemorating one year of not getting weird on each other poosy youre quite a girl he teased me the morning after a book party oh james i sighed from across the pillows and tangled sheets he looked at me and asked so why were you gay i sipped my tea and pondered my lifes choices it seemed a good idea at the time heather dune macadam the author of two books is working on her third dear james love pussy james aka simon worrall is the author of the poet and the murderer

text: date rape and rape within marriage are as serious as attacks carried out by strangers and judges should continue to punish them accordingly the sentencing guidelines council said today the council has proposed new guidelines that set out detailed instructions for judges on how to sentence more than different types of sex crime the guidelines are designed to reflect the harm caused to victims by sex offenders in the proposal the council backed existing case law that said judges should treat acquaintance rape and relationship rape no less seriously than attacks by strangers it also recommended a minimum of five years imprisonment for rapists whose victim was aged over a council spokeswoman said none of the recommendations in the guidelines should lead to reductions in average sentences the sex crimes detailed in the proposals would not be eligible for the reduction available for other types of offences she said the proposed guidelines which are out for consultation until the end of july suggested a victims age should be taken into account when deciding the level of punishment with extreme youth or age being an aggravating factor they also recommended higher minimum sentences in cases involving victims aged under or victims with any form of mental disorder other proposals included a month custodial sentence in cases where sexual activity was recorded and put on the internet and six years for the production of indecent photographs of children the councils deputy chairman sir igor judge said these guidelines emphasise the seriousness with which sexual offences should be treated by sentencing judges sentencers are particularly aware of the psychological as well as the physical impact of these offences on victims although the purpose of these guidelines is to achieve a consistent level of sentencing for the same type of offence they cannot deal with the specific impact of each individual offence which has to be taken into account by the sentencing judge the director of public prosecutions ken macdonald qc who is also a member of the council said the guidelines would help judges choose appropriate sentences for the new offences created by the criminal justice act in addition the dangerous offender provisions in the act apply to most of these offences so any offender who is found to present a significant risk of serious harm to other people will text: women may be securing a greater number of executive jobs but they are also suffering increasingly acute pay discrimination as they climb the career ladder according to new research government figures reveal that women are failing to reap the benefits enjoyed by men at the top of their professions the uks top male earners rake in a massive per cent more on average than the highestearning women women in fulltime work typically take home per cent less than their male counterparts but these figures show for the first time how much the gap increases as women move into more senior roles campaigners say this is stark evidence that the glass ceiling remains as real as ever others say there is a psychological barrier as women tend to underestimate their abilities and worth while men typically talk up their strengths and ignore their own weaknesses men are also research says much more likely to ask for a pay rise than women the figures compiled by the equal opportunities commission from the governments annual survey of hours and earnings show that men in the uk now need to earn just over a year to break into the top per cent women need a salary of to take them into the highest bracket per cent less than their male colleagues at the bottom of the pay scale the gap narrows to per cent jenny watson chair of the commission said that being a woman in the uk workforce comes at a cost whether for office cleaners or company directors there is a significant gap between the top mens earnings and the top womens she said our statistics show that women make up just per cent of directors at ftse companies per cent of the senior judiciary and per cent of senior police officers so its no surprise that the pay gap is widest for the highest earners researchers have grouped pay rates into bands and compared the most recent figures with based on the average fulltime hour week men needed to earn in to take them into the premier pay league in the figure was the equivalent figures for women are and the bottom per cent of men earn on average while the lowest female earners take home kate bellamy senior policy officer at the fawcett society which campaigns for equality between men and women in the workforce said it is appalling that years after equal pay laws came in women are still being shortchanged in the workplace her organisation has called on the government to introduce mandatory pay audits for all employers this is the only way we will be able to end the pay secrecy that allows discrimination to thrive especially in the private sector where pay gaps are widest she added the latest study comes just months after tony blairs women and work commission report which showed that since the sex discrimination act came into force in the gaps between the pay of men and women had narrowed only marginally for those in fulltime work it is per cent while the gap between male and female parttimers is per cent the authors of this study aim to reframe the debate about the gap and say direct discrimination is only one part of the equation the major cause of unequal pay according to the report is an employment structure designed for and by men campaigners have pointed to other factors such as the fact that women tend to have more responsibilities at home and are less inclined to commit to a longhours culture of presenteeism they highlight a psychological barrier one study showed that when a firm advertised a senior management role at a year they did not get one female applicant when they readvertised it at they were inundated by women psychologists say women in general are offered lower starting salaries are less likely to negotiate than men and once in a job are not as adept at asking for rises women tend to talk about their weaknesses and worry about being overpromoted while men trumpet their abilities the cost of inequality the macdonald hotels chain struck an thhour deal last month with elizabeth irons its text: there was a sliver of good news for women in business last week the number of female directors is slowly rising according to the research company experian women now make up of all uk directors which represents a small increase on last year however most of these women are working in companies employing no more than people with of female directors involved in firms with a turnover of less than m each year and men still dominate the boardrooms of larger companies only women are directors of companies employing more than people compared to men small but perfectly formed so why are women more likely to end up running smaller firms according to jane bruton editor of grazia magazine many have had enough of working in large firms and have set up their own businesses to avoid the frustrations of corporate life of the women who entered the grazia o x awards for women in business around of them had left senior positions within business to go it alone she says while for many women the driving force was a true entrepreneurial desire to create run and manage a business which they passionately believed in some also felt driven out by the lack of support and opportunity within big business for women with children and felt that they would either have to comprise career or kids to succeed glenda stone chief executive of aurora a womens networking organisation agrees women choose to run small businesses because they want to balance working with other commitments and working in a larger company doesnt allow them to do that she says many women who are involved in companies at boardroom level also get frustrated with the politics played by senior executives clare simpson now runs her own human resources consultancy business employment matters she used to be the hr director of a travel company with a seat on the board one of the reasons i left was because i felt i was spending more time involved in company politics than actually doing the job she says being on the board felt like being back in the playground fighting over who gets the sweets the flexibility of having her own business also appealed to simpson who says she was born to be a consultant she says i felt i could manage my own time more effectively and would be able to say yes or no to clients in a more considered manner adding that she finds running her own business much more rewarding too although the number of women running their own businesses is increasing auroras glenda stone says more could be done to boost numbers even further she suggests more financial education is key and adds getting access to money is not the problem the uk is awash with cash culture shocks britains leading employers organisation the cbi is encouraged by the increasing number of women becoming directors and particularly by the large number of younger women deciding to run their own business experians survey found that the proportion of female directors in the age range was higher at than in any other age group the survey also found that female directors are much more common in some industries than in others women are far more likely to be involved in education health social work or hospitality than in heavy industry or finance in britains utility companies for example there are male directors for every female director hanna haas policy adviser at the cbi says to get more women into these more maledominated businesses there needs to be better career advice for women in school and better work placements robin jones founded the catering company charlton house years ago the company employs people and expects to produce a turnover of m this year her boardroom is made up of three women and two men being involved at boardroom level has underlined the importance of making sure staff at all levels get their voices heard and their opinions noted especially in an industry where there is a high percentage of women working parttime she says she has no time for an office culture where people feel they have to be at their desks for long hours to prove they are doing their job well im always telling them to go home she says id happily kick them out of the building and lock the door so they couldnt sit there anymore jones is one of many women who agree there needs to be a radical change in the boardroom culture at large companies if they want to attract more female executives according to clare simpson boardrooms need to become more about meritocracy and getting a job done rather than about politics simpson also thinks it is important to encourage better representation of women on the boards of large companies it would be wrong just to accept that women are never going to be on the boards of big companies she says a company that lacks diversity of any kind loses the balance that different points of view give

text: there is nothing normal about sitting down to breakfast with seven men all in various states of undress there is also nothing normal or healing about tripping over the legs of men masturbating in the day room and there is nothing normal about sleeping next to a man you havent met before so says jolie goodman a campaigner for women only wards she believes that this type of thing is an everyday experience for many women in mental health settings where there is a continued tolerance of inappropriate sexual behaviour ranging from touching to rape despite real improvements in some places why is this still the case why does the physical and emotional safety of women in mental distress continue to be a low priority why are male staff members carrying out close observation of women in bathrooms and toilets in bedrooms during the night or even holding women down for forcible injections despite guidance to the contrary earlier this month government watchdog the national patient safety agency published a report revealing reported sexual incidents including reported rapes in mental health care settings between november and september this is almost one reported rape a month in of the reported rapes the alleged perpetrator was a member of staff the nhs litigation authority has also received three claims for compensation following unwanted pregnancies the report which the department of health initially tried to suppress also states that the problem is being significantly under reported to make matters worse over half the women who come in to patient wards have had previous experiences of violence rape domestic violence or child sexual abuse often women find their history ignored many practitioners lack the confidence and skills to recognise and talk about experiences of violence and abuse better training and support to enable staff to talk about past and present abuse is crucial unless we build a culture which allows abuse to be talked about abuses of power within mental health services will continue in chantells experience as a psychiatric patient it is hard to get people to believe what you tell them when she was she was admitted voluntarily to a psychiatric ward one night she woke to find one of the male nurses touching her and trying to get under the bedding and she started to scream she told her mother the next day but the nurse denied it and no action was taken she was told it was a symptom of her illness zara was in the grounds of a south london hospital when she was raped by a fellow patient she had complained on several occasions to staff about this patient following her around and making her feel uncomfortable the police were called but no further action was taken except that she was moved to another ward as the police felt her evidence would not stand up in court the npsa report found that the response of mental health trusts to serious incidents varied and it was not clear how many incidents were reported to the police in the mental health act commission found sexual harassment of women patients on over half the mixed wards surveyed while only of the wards had written policies on sexual harassment and abuse in the department of health pledged to abolish mixed sex wards and bring in separate sleeping bathroom and day facilities guidance to raise the profile of gender sensitive services more broadly was published but only one target was set on womens sleeping areas no extra funding was made available in the government reported that of health authorities were complying with the guidance on women only wards yet this is far from the experience of many mental health service users implementation has been patchy and the mental health charity mind has called for a national audit while in some areas real change and improvement have taken place in others the change has been largely semantic many health trusts have simply put a curtain between the male and female sleeping bays and claimed to comply with the guidance a mind survey in found that of women had been admitted to mixed sex accommodation did not feel it was helpful to their recovery and research by the brent user group in found womenonly spaces were often not respected by male staff visitors and patients this week is also the first anniversary of the report by the kerrhaslam inquiry over women reported abuse and rape over a year period by two nhs psychiatrists william kerr and michael haslam the inquiry report talked about a moral failing at the heart of the nhs the women reported the rapes to gps and other health professionals but with a few exceptions no action was taken nigel pleming who conducted the inquiry concluded that abuse would continue without action by the government professional bodies and others his recommendations included independent advocacy systematic data gathering and robust and mandatory training for mental health professions a year on we are still waiting for the government to say how it intends to respond to the report the inquiry only took place because women like kathy haq who was abused by william kerr when she was campaigned years later for it to take place they did not want other ladies to go through what we went through getting together and being listened to and believed was part of their healing process jonathan coe of witness a charity representing people who have been abused by health and social care professionals says our guess is that the npsa report greatly understates the true picture the government needs to do much more to ensure that allegations of sexualised behaviour by health and social care staff are recorded there needs to be a requirement in all health and social care training to discuss professional boundaries professional abuse and responsibilities to report if a practitioner thinks something is going on it is now time for meaningful targets to be set that include the voices of women service users and for funding to be made available to develop real alternatives we have talked enough now we have to act jeanette copperman jcoppermancityacuk is a senior lecturer in social work at city university not text: ten years ago next week a single called wannabe crashlanded at the top of the british charts it was a pearling record full of brio swagger and the addictive little elements that kicked off with its first line ill tell you what i want what i really really want and peaked with the mysterious claim that what its authors were after was a zigazigah within six months the inescapable spice girls were the subject of features in titles as diverse as nme and the spectator where they expounded the new theory of girl power summed up thus its about equality and fun and trying to rule your life when more academic voices weighed in however the girls were found wanting in the view of the american feminist jennifer pozner it was probably a fair assumption to say that a zigazigah is not spice shorthand for subvert the dominant paradigm here it was alleged was postfeminism revealed as a busted flush five supposedly empowered starlets whose diminutive nicknames and pushup bras suggested patriarchal business as usual extending the logic of that argument you might even charge them with responsibility for the wave of raunch culture recently summed up in these pages as womens collusion in their own objectification you could but youd be wrong the spice girls were shot through with absurdity and contradiction but in context their claim to be waging war on a testosteroneheavy consensus just about held up lest we forget found popcultural machismo at something of a peak the gallagher brothers expressing the opinion that birds are rubbish the euro tournament cementing a specious relationship between football and music and then came wannabe prompting the kind of talk that heralded their first appearance in the trade journal music week just when boys with guitars threatened to rule pop life an allgirl inyerface pop group have arrived with enough sass to burst that rockist bubble compare them to the pop people who followed in their wake and the sense of some almost accidental burst of joyous nonconformity gets even greater if the nonguitar end of the pop market now seems to be dominated by vacuous drones the spices not least when they fired their manager simon fuller in an act of quite splendid selfsabotage looked like something close to anarchists back on the terrain of sexual politics consider the absence of such contemporary promotional tics as regularly disrobing in your videos and turning in the obligatory fauxlesbian poses for the lads magazines in a modern context they look almost chaste so how did the postspice world go so awry a small part of the answer is bound up with their own greed more importantly girl power proved to be as nothing compared to altogether stronger cultural currents embodied by the contents of our newsstands and highstreet shops still for those who heard the opening bars of that song and sensed a new world there may be a faint glimmer of hope writing this i came across a copy of germaine greers the whole woman published in when spice hegemony was fading fast the spice girls did make a difference she wrote because their most passionate fans were eightyearold girls a study of childrens oral culture had found in the postspice climate that whereas half the space in school playgrounds used to be taken up by a selfselecting group of boys playing football girls clapping and dancing games were taking over if those fans were eight then theyll be coming up to now the great minds behind zoo nuts and love island might want to take note maybe just maybe something slightly more interesting might be around the corner johnharristheguardiancom

text: a single mother living in south london with her yearold son is advertising for household help on the web what she says she wants is a livein cleaner read on though and the job seems to require rather more than that the applicant must be kind reliable honest good speak fluent english and if you can be away for weekends or out for all of it this would be preferable when the applicant is in her duties include taking the child to school every day shopping going to the dry cleaners making the beds and changing them cleaning the whole house thoroughly twice a week doing all the laundry and ironing collecting the boy taking care of him after school cooking and giving him supper and babysitting in place of a mother who is out for three evenings a week this is not a cleaner this is a substitute parent what this mother is asking for is someone who will give her household and her child the care and attention she isnt around to provide but while she emphasises the need for kindness she seems to imagine she can expect an emotional engagement which she doesnt intend to reciprocate and which can be turned off at the end of every shift not only must the cleaner make him or herself scarce at weekends but she warns we value our privacy and want someone very independent as you will not be included in family activity i recognise what this mother is asking for i had livein nannies for almost years and this advertisement expresses baldly and painfully the impossible triple role most parents would secretly like their carers to provide they would like them to be expert and competent housewives loving and capable mother figures and to dematerialise like a ghost expressing no emotional needs the minute the parent returns to the house not many parents are as honest with themselves and their audience as this woman is but not many would be expecting this paragon of emotional selfsufficiency and generosity to materialise for the wages on offer here the salary is a week what this reflects is that the market for domestic help is changing fast five or years ago employing a livein nanny or carer was the preserve of the very well paid i once calculated that after paying for my nannys wage tax insurance car and living expenses i was left with less than a month had i been a single parent i could never have afforded one thats no longer so this week according to research by recruitment website gumtree the amount spent on the domestic market has tripled in the last decade now adding up to bn a year today one in three britons pays someone else to do work around the home whether gardening cleaning housekeeping or childcare and of those one in four say they could not manage without the paid help they get half of all parents are employers of some kind the leap in spending is partly a reflection of the largescale movement of women into the workplace of family breakdown and of the longer hours that many people are working but it is also a reflection of greater economic inequality the gap between rich and poor has widened even in the past decade the superrich the top and have pulled away from the rest of us but perhaps more important for the higher and middleincome working adults who are looking for ways to make their lives easier the bottom of society has got poorer in addition there are now large numbers of eastern european migrants and illegal immigrants who are willing to work for lower wages than britons would expect domestic help has become a possibility for whole swaths of people who would not have been able to afford it before while richer people can afford more of it employers at both ends of the scale are responding with alacrity whats remarkable is the range of jobs being offered nearly years ago when jonathan gathornehardy wrote his book the rise and fall of the english nanny he listed almost nostalgically the or so grades of job that could be expected in a victorian or edwardian household gathornehardy was convinced he had witnessed the end of the servant era what he had no way of knowing was that he was indeed writing just at a pivotal moment in english social history but it was not the one he thought it was his book was published in close to the highwater mark for british economic equality from the s to the s the wage gap narrowed steadily fuelled by a postwar ethic of greater fairness and by the power of the trade unions bluecollar workers were able to keep families comfortably off on a single wage but the unions were about to lose their power wives were about to be forced out to work to keep families going from the end of the decade the income gap would start to widen again at the same time the ideas of feminism were encouraging richer women to enter the workforce in pursuit of independence and equality their demand for domestic support and the supply of it was about to be reborn now its possible again to find private households advertising for weekend and holiday nannies assistant housekeepers cooks resident cleaners second au pairs maternity nurses gardeners handymen drivers and dogwalkers staff are being asked to sew greet and look after guests serve at formal tables assist with children on nannies days off deal with tradesmen and manage household accounts split shifts are not uncommon with staff expected to start early in the morning have three or four hours off in the middle of the day and work again until late fiveandahalf and sixday weeks are common too a single bachelor in central london needs a cookcleanerhousekeeper daily except sunday a chelsea household offers its assistant housekeeper mondays off and a halfday thursdays not negotiable it sounds just like the terms on offer to mary poppins but with none of the charm of fiction what runs through many of these advertisements whether at the top or bottom of the price range is a tone of slightly impatient precision employers accustomed to the role of consumer in the rest of their lives are setting out their desired combination of skills and qualities and waiting for it to arrive like a salad or a new desk most ads specify that there is no point in replying unless every requirement is met but it is noticeable that these lists of strict requirements contain a greater longing families want someone who will not only offer care but also warmth they hope that these jobs will be done with enthusiasm as if they were being done out of love rather than for money ads ask hopefully for people to be cheerful happy positive a onechild family in bedfordshire says of their housekeeper must be a good cook and always willing to please a family of five seeking a housekeeper for a sevenday week in london says they must be mature responsible and fanatical about cleanliness and hygiene a family looking for a home help in chiswick says they must love children even though the job doesnt include childcare and is only for nine hours a week and the worstpaid jobs are no different a single mother expecting a nanny to work a shocking hours a week for is nevertheless expecting happiness and friendliness at the price sometimes the wording indicates the inevitable disappointments in the past a london family offering a fantastic parttime housekeepers job to a loyal person say they need someone who will benefit from our caring and generous nature and not dilute it by not being forwardthinking and practically minded another single mother in the city adds i do not want to be a tyrant boss so it is important that you enjoy what you do and are happy to take responsibility for what needs to be done yet another lone mother offers a bonus if an au pair stays at least a year and gives three weeks notice before she leaves as otherwise it is just too disruptive for my child in part these exacting desires are just a recognition of the genuine difficulties of having strangers working within the home in our individualised culture homes have become the ultimate private space and our retreat from an often hostile universe in much of our lives we have been allowed to avoid any unsought intimacy when people come into our houses to work it may be necessary but it is also an intrusion they may bring alien values or patterns of behaviour one man describes sacking his housekeeper whom he scarcely ever saw because he could not bear the lingering smell of her perfume in the flat twice a week a single woman an academic talks of her mixed resentment and subsequent guilt at feeling forced to spend half an hour twice a week having coffee with her cleaner it is a pattern established years ago out of guilt at the unequal employeremployee relationship which she has never been able to break but she doesnt want this much human contact as she wryly says its more time than she has to spend with her best friend she wishes she could have the cleaners goodwill without her conversation these relationships have the capacity to be so tense complicated and mutually disappointing because most of us carry in our heads an idealised version of the family and the home home is a place of welcome and refuge families are happy supportive intimate and nuclear in practice modern life and our conflicting desire to be free to achieve in the outside world makes both of these ideals hard to achieve if we can we call in outsiders to support us and fill in the gaps they must do the tending tasks that family members would once willingly have done but we cannot love them for it we fear that they do it only because they are paid and the act of payment itself makes us inclined to feel suspicious and critical of our employees since we are buying something that we want why cant we get the perfect version of it why is there a hair on the floor or a child with homework unfinished conversely if all our expectations are met we may be even more unsettled domestic perfection can make us feel dangerously inadequate or even displaced gardeners who take too much pride in their gardens cleaners who are too proprietorial about their houses or nannies who are loved more than parents are all prone to being sacked these changes in our domestic arrangements are all part of what the american sociologist arlie hochschild calls the commercialisation of intimate life as her research shows in the united states the process of employing strangers to do what were once intimate household tasks has gone further than we yet have here there are companies who will write letters to your friends organise your family photograph albums and ceremonially scatter your relations ashes in the sea in your absence women living near your elderly parents will if paid call in to have the cups of tea or walks with them that you are too busy to manage yourself and parents who are worried about how well they are performing as family members can call in a professional evaluation company family for an indepth analysis of where they might be able to improve a common recommendation is the family memory package where a parent usually a father is encouraged to undertake activities with his children specifically in order to remember them later the question of memory is central to the issue of what we are doing when we give so many domestic tasks to others those tasks may be performed efficiently or even magnificently well but what we may miss when we absent ourselves is both the intrinsic satisfaction of the process itself the cakemaking the nappychanging or the herbgrowing and the chance to build longlived relationships with the people we love while we do so instead we may be creating lives full of fractured experiences for ourselves and more important for our children

text: while the law is set to change in favour of working mothers the majority of businesses are opposed to the governments plans to extend paid maternity leave according to latest figures from april mothers of new babies will be allowed to take nine months paid maternity leave instead of the current sixmonth limit however a survey published by law firm browne jacobson showed that most businesses had concerns about the changes to the law three quarters of the uk company directors who responded to the survey said they thought employers would be discouraged from hiring women of childbearing age which would be a breach of sex discrimination laws the figures showed that of employers did not support the extension to leave some were opposed to the changes and said that the legislation was yet another burden uk business can ill afford while would only support the measure if the government handled the administration less than one in five expressed unqualified support peter jones employment partner at browne jacobson said employers risk breaching not only sex discrimination law but also forthcoming age discrimination legislation if they seek to exclude potential mothers from the workforce from october this year employers will be breaking the law if they make recruitment decisions based on a persons age

text: though overshadowed by ruth kellys integration drivelfest yesterdays release of new research about work and fatherhood still received some media attention based on indepth interviews with fathers in professional and managerial jobs and on data from the british household panel study the headline findings of a team from bristol university were that most men do not change their working patterns because of having children and that they would rather have more flexible working hours than fewer of them there is no evidence that new involved fathers are adopting a female model of parenthood with parttime work and high levels of childcare said the sociologist dr esther dermott who led the research in a press release what professional men value most about their jobs is their ability to control their working hours so that they can leave early to go to school functions or parents meetings and this flexibility was also what other men most wanted these conclusions are significant and interesting but do they mean that new dad is and always will be a myth and a fantasy predictably those obsessed with reinforcing and policing what they regard as natural and traditional boundaries between the sexes have been excitedly spinning that this is so and using them as a stick with which to beat familyfriendly measures such as statefunded paternity leave what though can the less blinkered conclude the bristol findings certainly suggest a mismatch between some government thinking and what fathers desire one that may be exploited by the conservatives should their announcement also yesterday about flexible working practices appeal to the nations working dads but for broader insights into where fatherhood is going it seems productive to ponder the new research in the light of other work in this field at first glance the bristol discoveries seem at odds with for example a report from the equal opportunities commission saying that fathers are now doing a third of all childcare and to which i responded look more closely though and this may not be so that many fathers do not want to spend less time at work on account of having kids does not necessarily mean that their approach to fatherhood has not changed in comparison with those of previous generations of dads in other words it does not follow that not wanting to go to work for fewer hours on account of being dads means they do not spend more time looking after their kids or going about it in new ways the research in question also seems indirectly to confirm something else that success at work remains a bedrock priority for men and the male identity that this of itself remains unaltered by the fact of fatherhood should come as no surprise bringing home the bacon became a key paternal duty after the industrial revolution separated mens labour from the home and the legacy of this piece of cultural custom and practice is neither dishonourable nor likely to lose its purchase in a hurry also to necessarily state the obvious for as long as it is women rather than men who become pregnant give birth and breastfeed it is going to make sense for many couples for mister rather than missus to take on the extra burden of breadwinning after miss or master is born especially as he is likely to be the bigger earner meanwhile a lot of men still lack confidence in their ability to be good with kids while plenty of women surely feel ambivalent about change given that the domestic realm childcare included has such a history of being womens space in short the road towards new and improved forms of fatherhood is a long and slow one and it was always going to be that way so its worth restating what the journey is for or ought to be for it is not as the sneerers say to turn men into women neither is it to destroy the traditional family to go against nature in some way it is to help with the still larger task of helping families become warmer more stable egalitarian and democratic institutions in which dad is not a remote outsider the fact that he does not yet want to spend less time at work doesnt mean that change in that direction cannot happen or is not already happening ps i always try to respond to at least some readers comments on this occasion though that will be difficult by the time you read this ill be on a long car journey to a place where i cannot get online yes they really do exist i will however read the whole thread with interest on my return
